story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Resumen

 

Los colaboradores financian ideas que los apasionan y a la gente en la que confían. Estas son algunas cosas que puedes hacer en esta sección:

 
     
  • Preséntate y cuenta tu historia.
    •  
  • Describe brevemente tu campaña y explica por qué es importante para ti.
    •  
  • Expresa la magnitud de lo que logrará la ayuda de los colaboradores.
    •  
 

Recuerda, sé breve pero personal. Pregúntate: si alguien dejara de leer aquí, ¿estaría listo para colaborar?

 
 
 

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

 

Presenta más detalles:

 
     
  • explica cuánto financiamiento necesitas y a dónde va. Sé transparente y específico, la gente necesita confiar en ti para que quiera financiarte.
    •  
  • Cuéntale a la gente sobre tus recompensas exclusivas. ¡Haz que se entusiasmen!
    •  
  • Describe a dónde van los fondos si no logras la meta total.
    •  
 
 
 

El impacto

 

Explica tu campaña en mayor detalle y cuéntale a la gente la diferencia que hará su contribución:

 
     
  • explica por qué tu proyecto es valioso para el colaborador y para el mundo.
    •  
  • Describe tu historial de éxito en proyectos como este (si lo tienes).
    •  
  • Haz que la gente lo sienta real y genera confianza.
    •  
 
 
 

Riesgos y desafíos

 

Las personas valoran la transparencia. Sé abierto y destácate al ofrecer perspectivas sobre los riesgos y obstáculos que puedes enfrentar en el camino hacia lograr tu meta.

 
     
  • Comparte lo que hace que te destaques para superar estos obstáculos.
    •  
  • Describe tu plan para solucionar estos desafíos.
    •  
 
 
 

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

 

Algunas personas no pueden colaborar, pero eso no significa que no puedan ayudar:

 
     
  • pídele a la gente que difunda tu campaña y que genere eco.
    •  
  • Recuérdales que usen las herramientas para compartir de Indiegogo.
    •  
 
 

Y eso es todo.

story:
IsDaRevolution

From the director:


Having had no break into the film industry, I had to forge my own path.  Luckily, my ambitions materialized in 2008 with the first movie I directed "Ploning".


Since then, I've tried to reach back to the up-and-coming youth of Palawan.  I've looked for ways to inspire the young people and came up with the idea of leading workshops.  This has been my way of teaching young artists what it takes to chisel their way into this ever-changing world.


I've asked myself countless times, "what's the use of teaching the youth these principles if you can't focus the world's attention on their achievements?"  As well as "how can I help them earn a living by following their passion?"


I've since made it my intention and priority to devote my limited free time to cultivating these young and very eager minds.


This is the "Palawan Protege Project", setting off on a summer-long caravan from the North, all the way to the South of this beautiful island.  The caravan brings new media related workshops to the farthest reaches of Palawan.


The mission - is to find people who believe in the next generation as much as I do and to support their dreams here at home.  First, by teaching them the right values and ethics that will bring out the best in the heirs of this majestic island.


Please help the youth of Palawan by supporting on Palaweno kid at the price of $25.  Your money will directly affect a child who aspires to make their dream a reality.


The Palawan Protege Project is already in full effect and will culminate with an International New Media Artists Convergence on July 3rd through the 5th in Puerto Princesa City.

Let's combine our efforts to make this vision come true for the future of our great island the dreamers of tomorrow.


Matamang Salamat,


Dante Nico Garcia

Founder, IsDa Revolution

story:
CAMPAIGN HAS MOVED TO: http://igg.me/at/vab/x/8936154

Many people don't like reading a lot of text, so the 2-panel comics and art in the Vegan Artbook are the perfect solution to spread the vegan message in a creative and thought-provoking way.

The Vegan Artbook MILD contains over 300 pages of colourful artwork and comics each, focused on veganism, ethics, the environment, food, peace, love and animals. Aside from spreading cuteness, the books also raises awareness and shows people how they can make healthier and more ethical choices in their daily lives... all via artwork and short comics with 1 to 6 panels each!

These unique books are therefore the perfect gift for vegans and vegetarians or people who are interested in this ethical life philosophy. Because of the colourful cartoonish art style, the books especially aim at people who are visually oriented and young people such as teenagers (who often don’t like to read a lot of text) and it teaches our future generations how to make the world a better place.

I've been working on these books for many months but because I am still studying, I lack the funds to publish the Vegan Artbook MILD. The Vegan Artbook MILD is planned for an april release and I need your help to make it happen. If you think my project is valuable, please help me realize it by helping me fund the publication of this book. Everything will be produced environmentally friendly, but also in very high quality on smooth recycled paper! Printing a full-colour book like this with 320 pages in small quantities is quite expensive here, so I'll be very grateful for every bit of help I can get on this.

This is one of the unique VAB mugs you will receive if you claim reward 9, 10 or 11. There is also a different design availible.

Your money will be used for the printing and publication of the artbook. All other costs (like copic markers & other drawing materials) will be paid with the money from my own pocket. Vegan Artbook has been a non-profit project until now. The previous book (SPICY) was a free book and people only paid for printing and shipping costs. I think that, for a project like this, money isn't important. The most important thing is spreading compassion and literally save lives that way.

Don't forget to check the video for more information!
And please share a link to this crowdfunding page!
Thank you everyone! I love you all!

story:
Our Story

My Name is Chad Collins and I am a member of the Kestrel Clay dynamic duo, along with Megan Jones.  We are teachers and ceramic artists based in Baltimore, MD looking to expand our business and teaching practice.  We are both dedicated artists who have recently begun expanding from private sales and limited gallery representation to small markets and festivals.  The Kestrel Clay Throw-Down is our way of having fun and reaching out the online community. We will each run an independent campaign to see who can raise the most funds toward getting us to the NCECA conference this year in Kansas City, MO.  The winner gets bragging rights and the loser gets a bucket of muddy clay dumped on their head (with a video of course so that you can enjoy it as much as we do!). 

What We Need & What You Get From Us!


We need $1300 bare minimum to travel to Kansas City March 16-23 to participate in NCECA's annual conference.  This venue will give us access to international artists, organizations, residency opportunities, and vendors that will help guide us along the path of successful art entrepreneurs. 

$600- Round Trip Flights for two

$700- 4 day Conference Passes for two

We are fortunate enough to have family in the area, who are graciously letting us crash in our (Megan's) old bedroom. So housing for the event is free! Lucky us! 

Any additional monies raised beyond these needs will go toward the development of Kestrel Clay as a solvent business. This would include but not be limited to advertising, and building toward studio materials such as a raku kiln and decal printer for examples.  

  • What do you get out of this you ask?  Based on the level of your support to either of our campaigns you will receive a unique one of a kind reward made by the artist you chose to support.  
  • For Supporting Team Chad, who is a potter and painter, you will have the option to receive hand thrown cups,bottles, jars and place settings that are each unique and will have a special voice in your home. Hand made art elevates even a simple meal and brings a new aesthetic to your home.

$1- A thank you email from both Chad and I!

$10- A hand-drawn doodle postcard that will be sent to you in the mail!

$30- Your choice of (one) Mug or Tumbler.

$50- Your choice of (two) mugs or tumblers.

$80- Whiskey set. One bottle and two half-tumblers.

$100- Your choice of (four) mugs or tumblers.

$100-Set of two canister jars.
$140- Place setting. This will include: 1 mug/tumbler, 1 large plate, 1 small plate, and 1 soup bowl.
$200- Ceramic Urn, approximately sized to 14". Chad will work with you to determine the best form and glazes.
$350- Throwing Workshop! [Baltimore Only!] Work with Chad at the Potters Guild for 6 sessions, learning the art of throwing on the wheel. By the end you will leave with your own functional pottery.
[Images Coming soon!]
 To see what Megan has to offer (boo), go here.
 https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/nceca-research-trip-the-kestrel-clay-throw-down/x/6425487#/

The Impact

Your contribution will make is possible for us gain access to a larger world of artists and craftsmen. Many who have already made their mark on the world and are willing to show us the way.  This research trip will make us better artists and better teachers.

Risks & Challenges

Megan and I are incredibly devoted artists, whose passion for making drives us in the studio all hours of the day and night. reaching our goal as well as sharing our gifts is a joy and a privilege. Any support you can spare will help us reach our goal. With ceramics, there is always risk, such as a piece cracking or glaze failures, but rest assured, we will work through the night if it means giving you a great product. No matter if the campaign is funded or not, you will still receive your artwork.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, (and we totally understand) but that doesn't mean that you can't help:

  • Make some noise, spread the word about The Kestrel Clay Throw-Down share with your friends and decide who will get the bucket of mud.
  • Don't for get to share us on Facebook, twitter and the rest of the internets.


Thank you so much for your time!

story:
THE COSMIC CAROUSEL Tour 2016 is scheduled for lift off!

In our modern, dis/connected world, The Cosmic Carousel encourages its audience to fully engage with one another in a unique interactive experience, and to enjoy being in the moment together as a collective unit.


The Experience

At first glance, The Cosmic Carousel stands as a futurist large-scale sculpture; a gravity-defying work of art balancing on a single thread reflecting its surrounding environment from its mirror polished aluminum skin; a mesmerizing experiment  in form, movement, and concept.

Upon further exploration, the sculpture comes alive as a kinetic interactive plaything, inviting the onlooker to become the participant.

Those brave enough will work together to climb aboard and cooperatively steer the ship, allowing interaction and communication to pull them into the collective experience. 

The more these daring cosmonauts help each other, the faster the ship flies in a 360-degree rotation, landing these adventurous souls in an experiential state of bliss, free from the bonds of their every day existence where they can truly connect on a human level.


The Sculpture

Hovering at 23 x 18 ft wide and 17 ft tall, this monumental sculpture features a mirror-polished aircraft grade aluminum finish, programmable RGB LED lighting effects, and a 360-degree conversation pit at the helm.

Since its debut in the Black Rock Desert in 2012, The Cosmic Carousel has been on a mission seeking landing sites where the audiences can board and be a part of the human experience. 

Thanks to our friends at m0xy, the sculpture has been on private display in Oakland, California. As it has been standing by on deck, we have evaluated some necessary maintenance and upgrades in preparation for launch this Spring. 

Your donation will ensure the success of our preparations!


The Exhibition

The Cosmic Carousel is scheduled to go on tour May 2016, launching from m0xy and proceeding to several public event engagement stops in California and Nevada where an extended exhibition is in the works. We are working towards making this a reality, but our excursion is contingent on funding. A donation given by you, will help us bring this astonishing sculpture to exhibits across the United States. Additionally, after making many appearances on the West Coast, we would take flight to Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to be displayed during the International Sculpture Conference. We are open to adding flight stops to our tour, please contact us if you have any suggestions or inquiry to book. 


The Plan

Our total budget for the scheduled tour is $24,000. We have been granted $9,000 toward this total from various sources. We are grateful for your interest in helping us to raise the additional $15,000 we need to complete our budget.

Your contribution can get The Cosmic Carousel in flight!

The $15,000 from this Indiegogo Campaign, in tandem with the seed funds will go directly towards the necessary equipment, materials, maintenance, and specialized members of support staff to prepare the sculpture, and transportation costs. With your help we can bring The Cosmic Carousel experience to a wide audience across the country in 2016.


Your Donations

Your contribution will support our efforts to bring the Cosmic Carousel to a nationwide audience of all ages. Your contribution will ensure the safety and success of the tour, and the future of The Cosmic Carousel Sculpture!                                           

If you wish to have a tax deductible donation, please email us at cosmiccarouselsculpture@gmail.com for more information.                                         Thank you for your time and generous support.

story:
The Chapel as a Canvas

The Main Post Chapel at Schofield Barracks is a multi-denominational, multi-use chapel serving all of our service members, veterans, and their families on Oahu. But instead of being a warm, inviting place, its walls are cold and bare. The Pacific Peace Art Project is trying to remedy this by creating a custom tribute art installation to decorate and enliven the community space. 

Research has shown that artwork featuring nature, water, peaceful landscapes and outdoor vistas can have very positive effects on the mental and emotional health of soldiers suffering from PTSD. Beautiful art can also be very uplifting for family members who’ve lost loved ones in the line of duty. For the Pacific Peace Art Project, well-known artist Bill Braden will depict peaceful, therapeutic panoramas featuring creative images of water, sky and coastline. The artwork will turn the chapel into a place of comfort and solace, where families can heal and celebrate the lives of fallen soldiers. The project will benefit over 200,000 people per year, including visitors, active duty and reserve military members, National Guard troops, the civilian population of Wahiawa and military retirees throughout Oahu.

One of many Bill Braden oil on canvas studies for the Pacific Peace Art Project

A Decade in the Making 

The concept for the Pacific Peace Art Project began in 2004, when the Main Chapel’s Father Herron recognized the need to revitalize the chapel walls and contacted artist Bill Braden. Together, they began to imagine the artistic possibilities and how the artwork might unite visitors who are suffering. In 2012, a private philanthropic foundation committed to providing seed funding for the project. The theme evolved from "A Memorial to the Largest Deployment of Schofield since World War II" to its present adaption, “Pacific Peace Art", featuring views of the Pacific Ocean, the Hawaiian sky and our beautiful shorelines. In February 2014, Army Garrison Commander Colonel Daniel Whitney officially endorsed the project and designated Father Herron as the project leader. 

Pacific Peace Fundraising Efforts

Unfortunately military personnel are not allowed to fund raise so funds for this project must come from the private sector. Phase One, the year 2016, is to raise the funds for the large canvas (20’ by 20’) painting for the back wall of the chapel. We have a $20,000 matching grant from Sammons Enterprises of which we still need to match $17,500. Every dollar that is donated, minus the crowd funding fees, will be matched by them up to $17,500. Added to this we already have received a $10,000 grant from an anonymous Foundation and over $6,200 from individuals in the community.

When we reach our Indegogo goal of $17,500 we will be halfway to our goal of $100,000 for the project. Bill Braden will begin the actual paintings once we reach this milestone. The Pacific Arts Foundation, a 501 (3) (c), is serving as the fiscal sponsor of this project. Therefore a portion of donations received should be, please confirm with your CPA, tax deductible. The Pacific Arts Foundation’s mission is to create inspiring cultural arts projects that serve the community.

With your help we can create inspiring cultural art that will serve the community.

Artist Bill Braden, BFA in Sculpture 1980, RISD, Providence, Rhode Island 

Known for his work in public scale art, Bill Braden, assisted by his wife Jinny, will create the Pacific Peace Art Project mural in the Main Post Chapel. The creative couple have successfully completed many large-scale public art commissions, including “The Best Beaches of Hawaii” for the City and County of Honolulu, several large paintings for the North Shore Community Land Trust, a 24’ x 12’ painting of Shark’s Cove for the Malama Pupukea Waimea Marine Life Sanctuary Organization a 22’ x 14’ piece for what is now the Hilton Waikoloa. The paintings themselves will be mural style in Bill’s Reef and Sky Series genre — a series he was first commissioned to create for the lobby of the Queen Liliuokalani Gardens Condominiums in the 1980s. Visit BillBraden.com for more on the artist.

The Pacific Peace Art Project will encompass a total of seven canvases, including two sets of diptychs and three individual pieces. Due to their large size, the paintings will be fabricated in a North Shore studio built specifically for creating oversize pieces of artwork.

Phase I, a total of $100,000, which is the basis for this request, will be a 20' X 20' diptych painting (each panel measuring 10' high x 20' wide) of "Pacific Sky" and "Pacific Sea.” These will be featured on the large back wall of the main nave in the sanctuary. 

Phase II begins in year two and will incorporate smaller canvases. A diptych 8' x 20' (2 panels at 8' x 10’) of "Deep Pacific Sea" at the entrance foyer will welcome visitors. Flanking the altar will be paintings of shallower water. The altar, which is positioned higher in the sanctuary, will showcase three 8' x 8' single canvases whose scenes depict shallow water and land.

Together the two phases will fulfill the concept of creating peaceful art in the Main Post Chapel. The deep Pacific Ocean piece “At Sea” will rest in the narthex/entrance foyer to greet all visitors. Entering the sanctuary/nave, guests will experience the “Sky and Reef” piece from within the safety of the lagoon. The altar is flanked by a scene of shallow water, perhaps views of Army Beach in Waianae and Army Beach in Mokuleia.
story_txt:
Father Herron of the Main Post Chapel and artist Bill Braden review a study of the artwork for the back wall. Imagine the artwork three times the size of what is pictured here.The Chapel as a CanvasThe Main Post Chapel at Schofield Barracks is a multi-denominational, multi-use chapel serving all of our service members, veterans, and their families on Oahu. But instead of being a warm, inviting place, its walls are cold and bare. The Pacific Peace Art Project is trying to remedy this by creating a custom tribute art installation to decorate and enliven the community space. Research has shown that artwork featuring nature, water, peaceful landscapes and outdoor vistas can have very positive effects on the mental and emotional health of soldiers suffering from PTSD. Beautiful art can also be very uplifting for family members who’ve lost loved ones in the line of duty. For the Pacific Peace Art Project, well-known artist Bill Braden will depict peaceful, therapeutic panoramas featuring creative images of water, sky and coastline. The artwork will turn the chapel into a place of comfort and solace, where families can heal and celebrate the lives of fallen soldiers. The project will benefit over 200,000 people per year, including visitors, active duty and reserve military members, National Guard troops, the civilian population of Wahiawa and military retirees throughout Oahu.One of many Bill Braden oil on canvas studies for the Pacific Peace Art ProjectA Decade in the Making The concept for the Pacific Peace Art Project began in 2004, when the Main Chapel’s Father Herron recognized the need to revitalize the chapel walls and contacted artist Bill Braden. story:
Leslie Olabisi 

Actress. Host. Model: ARTIST

UPDATE: GIVING TUESDAY!!!!
Why, you ask?

It is important that my campaign get funded because I have and continue to work on progressing my performance career. But there is only so far I can go with no agent, no manager, and little access. 
But with a SAG-AFTRA membership, I get access to castings, events, and other resources to perfect my craft and make new connections for more work with good wages. Being a Union member tells the world that you are serious about going to the next level.
With that access, I plan to use the opportunity to promote great causes that I believe in- youth, education, art, culture, and connecting people to resources.

My funders can virtually come along for the ride. Instead of a tech project for instance, where it comes to market and that's it, with me you can see the progress I will continue to make as time continues and I will share the experience with my supporters- events, live tweets, broadcasts, etc.

see full story: www.leslieolabisi.com/currentprojects
  • The target is 60 days from Monday, October 12, 2015.

story:
He Make This Art Installation Come to Life by donating!

$30 – Opening Night Ticket ($35 At Door)

 *** Paintings available for Pre- Sale ***


 POP UP ART SHOW:


EVOLUTION: A Meditation on the cycle of
Destruction, Regeneration, Reflection & Rebirth.


An interactive, multi-dimensional experience featuring the art of


AMANDA SHAFRAN

 and other stories of growth.


Amanda Shafran’s surrealist, figurative paintings are inspired by the relationship between the anatomy of the body and the anatomy found in all living things.


THURSDAY FEB 25th 

FLOATING LOTUS 

39 W 56th ST PENTHOUSE 


7:30 pm- 11:30 pm



WHAT IS THIS PROJECT ALL ABOUT?

Check out our Gallery Page to see some images! 

 Hosted by Floating Lotus, EVOLUTION examines the undeniable growth and transformation that often follows in the aftermath of both internal and external, public and private destruction. Contemplation of this universal, natural law of the universe allows for the continued, ever changing cycle of death & birth, with the surrendering away of the old and clearing space for the new.  Change.

This Installation invites the viewer to contemplate their own feelings surrounding destruction and expansion. By pairing art with sensory aligning modalities such as music, physical movement, aromatherapy, related pieces of writing, and first hand personal stories of growth, this installation will carve out space for the viewer to experience a guided multidimensional sensory experience, and confront the related and changing nature of their own Mind, Body, & Spirit, for a full spectrum, integrative, transformational experience.

Amanda Shafran’s surrealist, figurative paintings are inspired by the relationship between the anatomy of the body and the anatomy found in all forms of nature. Amanda, an artist, costume designer, and Fibromyalgia survivor, realized during the healing process that the act of mapping her body in a sketchbook allowed a visual and mental, neuroplastic relationship to develop between her anatomy, and the naturally occurring patterns found in all forms of life.

Now for the second time Amanda has a chance to show her work. This is installation is aimed at empowering men & women to reflect on their own stories, and unapologetically face the wisdom within themselves. By sharing our stories, we heal universal wounds.

EVOLUTION is a 1Billion Rising Event. It is a call to rise and create a social revolution around art bodies and marginalized women. 

www.onbillionrising.org


Proceeds of this installation will be donated to Exhale to Inhale, which empowers survivors of trauma to reclaim their lives through the practice of yoga.

Yoga Benefit in our space TBD 



REWARDS- This is what we have in store for you! 

$30 – LIMTED EDITION “Rebirth” Magnets to the first 50 people to buy opening night tickets!!  (include photo) + Opening Night Ticket

$50 – LIMITED EDITION PRINT Signed and embellished pen & Pencil  cardstock 8 x 10 (to first 50 patrons!! )+ Opening Night Ticket

$100- single personalized and tailored private yoga/ meditation session with Amanda + Opening Night Ticket

$250- Signed and embellished archival 10x14 prints +  2 Opening Night Tickets

$500- Two signed and embellished archival 10 x14 prints + 4 Opening Night Tickets

$1000- Pre- purchase small Original painting + 4 Opening Night Tickets

$2000- Pre-purchase large Original painting + 4 Opening Night Tickets

$2,500+ - Pre- purchase Original Painting + PRODUCER CREDIT + 6 Opening Night Tickets


BUDGET:  This is what we plan to do with your donation!

We've used our own resources (And $650 from our first IndieGogo Campaign!)  to find a space, gather needed materials & supplies, Print all necessary PR materials, and anything Printed for opening night,  But, we still need some Helping Hands  to make this Art Come Alive! 


PR                           $500

Lighting                $1000

Framing                $1500

Production          $1500

Opening               $1000

TOTAL :            $5,500


THE TEAM: 

Producer:                                    FLOATING LOTUS

                                                        http://www.floatinglotus.com

Producer:                                     Eyal Dagan

Producer:                                    Amanda Shafran

PR:                                                 COMING SOON 

Exhibition & Lighting:              Ashuman Bhatia

Design Assistant:                     Jordana Braverman

Contributing Storytellers:     COMING SOON 


BIOS

Amanda Shafran

HI! I’m Amanda Shafran.

I’m an international costume designer, yogi, and artist living on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, with my amazing husband of six years.

I'm originally from Long Island, NY, though I've always been a city girl at heart. I love art, nature, history, yoga, and a good conversation. In college I studied English and Theater. I went on to pursue the language of clothes and construction while getting an M.F.A. in Design for Stage and Film at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, with a concentration in costume design. There, I spent three years studying illustration, fashion history, clothing construction, drawing & painting, and dramaturgy. I learned how to channel the technical language of color, form, shape, and texture through the lens of a story.

After graduating, A series of assistantships directly after earning my M.F.A prepared me to stand on my own two feet as a designer, but my body began to quickly deteriorate with the hard physical demands of carrying heavy bags of fabric around the clock, while under the tense constriction of unrelenting stress.

It was at this point I learned that I also have Fibromyalgia and PTSD, two complicated neurological and mind/ body disorders that simply didn’t fit into my otherwise on track lifestyle or life plan.

My mind wanted to keep working at warp speed, however I couldn’t change the hard facts of my body. I decided to invest in myself. Somehow, this ended up in finding a way to use my skills with color, form, shape, and texture as a lens to communicate my own story. I devoted everything I had to self-care, ultimately finding healing in a combination of hands on massage treatments, acupuncture, Yoga, Meditation, medication, and journaling to be the ultimate aid on both a physical, psychological, and spiritual level. (And A LOT of therapy!)

Now, in addition to theatrical design, I create drawings and paintings as a lens into my story, with the aim of empowering other women and men to take ownership of and love their own personal minds, bodies, and spirits. I also share what I have learned by teaching private, group, and corporate Yoga & Meditation.

To see more, Take a look at www.amandashafran.com
Floating Lotus
Eastern medicine sees us all as a set of carefully balanced forces or energies. These forces animate and give us the ability to create an inspired and healthy human life. When they fall out of harmony, we experience disease, fatigue, anxiety, depression, pain and other sufferings. We founded Floating Lotus to help bring those inner forces back into balance.
 http://www.floatinglotus.com


This campaign is an amazing opportunity to support healing and cultivation of  community through the arts. 


If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help! 

Help us get the word out and make some noise! Share this on instagram, Facebook, or tell your friends through email. 

We are so grateful for your time and support!!

<3 

We can't wait to share this project with you!
Let's Rise and Create a Fierce, Compassionate Revolution!

story:
Who We Are

Hi, we're Sundress Publications, and we're in the process of building a new barn at Firefly Farms, our forty-five acre instructional, residency, and outreach center. Much of the equipment we have for our visiting artists and staff—including a drafting table, antique letterpress, and specialized tools—must share space with livestock feeds and farm equipment in our basement. This barn will allow us to reclaim the space and transform it from a general-purpose storage area to a workspace for visiting artists and writers.


And now, a political advertisement from Jayne the Donkey:

It's that time again, where the best and brightest of our country come together to talk about the important issues that affect all American citizens in order to move our nation forward. Where the unbiased media discusses and weighs the best ideas and informs us, the citizens, who we could democratically elect for our next leader.

JUST KIDDING!

It's time for a bunch of grown human beings—let's be honest, mostly straight white males—to yell at one another on stage! It's time for gaffes, sound bites, and the general denigration of social progress!

So, why not just skip to the chase and vote for a REAL jackass this election season?

That's right. Jayne, the Sundress Academy for the Arts donkey, is throwing his hilarious donkey-sized hat into the ring to be the new leader of the free world. Because he's an ass, but an ass you can trust!


What We Need and What You Get

In order to get Jayne's political career started, we need to construct his campaign headquarters, a

16' x 32' barn that will shelter him and his herd through the silly season and right into the primaries! With plenty of covered seating for Jayne and his staff of six sheep and a cranky goat who serves as his social media coordinator, this space will keep them working strong all throughout the cold mountain weather.


Not only will this space be able to house a small herd, but it will also serve as their personal pantry, housing a hayloft that will keep them in the grain all winter! This space will also help to free up room in the basement so that visiting residents—I mean, VIPs—will have more space for painting, woodworking, and more!

Donate now in order to help us raise the $5,000 we need to buy the lumber, roofing, siding, paint, and trimmings for this fantastic new campaign space, and you will receive any number of excellent perks—your own “Jayne for President” buttons, bumper stickers, mousepads, plus lots of swag from Jayne's good friends over at Sundress Publications!

All donors will be invited to a spring barnraising shindig to celebrate the campaign's success!

All donations for this campaign are tax-deductible and go to support Jayne's number-one cause—the arts! 

 

Other Ways to Help

If you can't support Jayne financially, be sure to tell your friends about this campaign on social media and be sure to Like Jayne's supporters at the Sundress Academy for the Arts over on Facebook and follow Jayne on Twitter @SundressPub. You can also find out more about how to volunteer at Firefly Farms here!

We thank you for your support, your vote, and your belief in a transparent political system where you know that your leader is a total jackass.

It's time for a bunch of
grown human beings—let's be honest, mostly straight white males—to
yell at one another on stage! It's time for gaffes, sound bites, and
the general denigration of social progress!

So, why not just skip to
the chase and vote for a REAL jackass this election season?

That's right. Jayne, the
Sundress Academy for the Arts donkey, is throwing his hilarious donkey-sized hat into the
ring to be the new leader of the free world.  Because he's an ass,
but an ass you can trust!


What We Need and What
You Get

In order to get Jayne's
political career started, we need to construct his campaign
headquarters, a 

16' x 32' barn that will
shelter him and his herd through the silly season and right into the
primaries! With plenty of covered seating for Jayne and his staff of
six sheep and a cranky goat who serves as his social media
coordinator, this space will keep them working strong all throughout
the cold mountain weather.

Not only will this space
be able to house a small herd, but it will also serve as their
personal pantry, housing a hayloft that will keep them in the grain
all winter!  This space will also help to free up room in the
basement so that visiting residents—I mean, VIPs—will have more
space for painting, woodworking, and more! 


Donate now in order to
help us raise the $5,000 we need to buy the lumber, roofing, siding,
paint, and trimmings for this fantastic new campaign space, and you
will receive any number of excellent perks—your own “Jayne for
President” buttons, bumper stickers, mousepads, plus lots of swag
from Jayne's good friends over at Sundress Publications!All donors will be invited to a spring barnraising shindig to celebrate the campaign's success!

All donations for this
campaign are tax-deductible and go to support Jayne's number-one
cause—the arts!   

Other Ways to Help

If you can't support Jayne
financially, be sure to tell your friends about this campaign on
social media and be sure to Like Jayne's supporters at the Sundress Academy for the Arts over on Facebook and follow Jayne on Twitter
@SundressPub. You can also find out more about how to volunteer at
Firefly Farms here!

We thank you for your
support, your vote, and your belief in a transparent political system
where you know that your leader is a total jackass.

story:
The Adaptive Skate Kollective is a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting awareness, understanding and acceptance of disability. Our mission is to eliminate social barriers and promote inclusiveness in athletic and educational programs.  

Help us publish! 

We're so close! With your help we will finish the publishing process. You'll receive your copy immediately after we go to print. 
We are partnering with other non-profit organizations to provide this book for victims of traumatic injury and amputation. Coloring is a great way to cope and heal.

story:
Eres amante de la cocina creativa, las creaciones novedosas, las artes plásticas y culinarias? Perra Hambre es uno de los primeros restaurantes en la Ciudad de México que combina la expresión artística de un foro-galería con la cocina de autor, la cual mezcla de manera creativa los principios de la cocina tradicional, los de la Nouvelle Cuisine y la Cocina de Fusión.

You are a lover of creative cuisine, the innovative creations, visual and culinary arts? Bitch Hunger is one of the first restaurants in Mexico City that combines the artistic expression of a forum-gallery with the cuisine, which mixes creative way the principles of traditional cuisine, the Nouvelle Cuisine and Kitchen Fusion.

Para su reapertura hemos decidido recurrir al crowdfunding dándole la oportunidad a todos aquellos amigos, clientes, seguidores e interesados a participar activamente con nosotros para reanudar este proyecto con aún más fuerza que antes.

For its reopening, we have decided to resort to crowdfunding giving the opportunity to all those friends, clients, supporters and stakeholders to actively participate with us to resume this project with even more force than before.

Estamos desarrollando un espacio en el cual la ecología, el arte y el gusto culinario se unen en una simbiosis creativa. Se parte de este nuevo desarrollo!

We are developing a space in which ecology, art and culinary taste come together in a creative symbiosis. It is part of this new development!

Con tu ayuda queremos ser un referente en la Cocina de autor en México y consolidarnos como un espacio abierto a la diversidad cultural para artistas que impulsa proyectos creativos y de vinculación social con e fin de transmitir las diferentes areas de las bellas artes e incluiremos, por supuesto el arte CULINARIO.

With your help we want to be a leader in the Cuisine in Mexico and consolidate as an open cultural diversity that drives creative artists and social bonding projects and to convey the different areas of the fine arts space and will include, for Of course the culinary arts.

Estamos desarrollando un espacio en el cual la ecología, el arte y el gusto culinario se unen en una simbiosis creativa. Se parte de este nuevo desarrollo!

We are developing a space in which ecology, art and culinary taste come together in a creative symbiosis. It is part of this new development!

Podrás apoyarnos adquiriendo uno de los paquetes de regalo que podrás canjear una vez terminado el proyecto mediante en el siguiente link o depositando en efectivo en las tiendas oxxo / 7eleven o en banco Santander utilizando el número 5579 1000 3216 1737

You can support us becoming one of the gift packages that can redeem once completed the project through the following link or by depositing cash in oxxo / 7eleven stores or bank Santander using the number 5579 1000 3216 1737

Perra Hambre nació por el deseo de crear un espacio con cabida para diferentes expresiones artísticas y culturales. Poco a poco se fue consolidando y vimos la oportunidad de apoyar al comercio mexicano liberándonos del uso de marcas comerciales y productos industrializados; así nació nuestro sello que nos llevó a tener una gran cartera de clientes.

Perra Hambre was born by the desire to create a space with room for different artistic and cultural expressions. Gradually she was consolidated and saw an opportunity to support the Mexican trade freeing the use of trademarks and industrial products; thus he was born our label that brought us to have a large customer base.


Por lo tanto Perra Hambre no se debe ver como un restaurante de cocina de autor, sino como un foro para expositores, músicos, actores, artesanos, diseñadores, gente con algún proyecto innovador y que no cuente con el espacio para su difusión y comercialización. Promovemos el desarrollo sustentable utilizando mobiliario y decoración realizados con materiales de rehusó que agregan valor ambiental y social al proyecto.

Therefore Perra Hambre it should not look like a restaurant cuisine, but as a forum for exhibitors, musicians, actors, artisans, designers, people with an innovative project and that does not have space for its distribution and marketing. Promote sustainable development using decorative items made with materials refused to add to the project environmental and social value.

Queremos ser parte de la solución ante la complejidad de México, por lo que compramos productos nacionales directamente a los productores o empresas mexicanas. Buscamos en los bazares de diseño como Libre Liebre,  bazar cree y crea en México entre otros, a aquellas personas que tengan productos gastronómicos artesanales de calidad. Nos entusiasma la idea de crear una red comercial entre productores artesanales para estimular el consumo de la economía local.

We want to be part of the solution to the complexity of Mexico, so we buy domestic products directly from producers or Mexican companies. We search bazaars design as Free Hare, bazaar believes and believes in Mexico among others, those who have handmade quality delicacies. We are excited to create a retail network between artisan producers to stimulate consumption of the local economy.

Breve reseña

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

Contamos con equipo de cocina de primera suficiente para operar y con una amplia experiencia en manejo y operación de restaurantes y logística de eventos culturales. Ahora solo necesitamos rentar una locación adecuada, preferentemente en el centro de le ciudad de México, en donde ya tenemos apalabrado un excelente local. Con que logremos recaudar rentaremos y adecuaremos la locación y si nos alcanza compraremos algo equipo de audio.

What we need and what you get

We first kitchen equipment sufficient to operate and extensive experience in management and operation of logistics restaurants and cultural events. Now we just need to rent a suitable location, preferably in the center of Mexico City will, where we have bespoken an excellent local. With that we achieve raise will rent and will adapt the location and if you buy something reaches audio equipment.


El impacto

- Ser un referente en la Cocina de autor en Distrito Federal y el país.

- Consolidarnos como un espacio abierto a la diversidad cultural para artistas emergentes y consagrados de las diferentes disciplinas artísticas.

- Impulsar proyectos artísticos y de vinculación social relevantes para la localidad que ayuden a generar nuevos públicos.

- Ofrecer formación artística y cultural especializada, general y de interés para sectores vulnerables de la sociedad con costo accesibles, pago en especie o el otorgamiento de becas acorde a los sectores o población beneficiaria.

- Ser una fuente de empleo para la población que por sus actividades es complejo acceder a un empleo de tiempo completo (jóvenes, estudiantes, madres solteras, amas de casa. Sectores vulnerables por mencionar algunos)

The impact

- Be a leader in the Cuisine in Mexico City and the country.

- Consolidate as an open cultural diversity for emerging and established artists from different artistic disciplines space.

- Encourage relevant artistic and social links to the town to help generate new public projects.

- Offering specialized, comprehensive and relevant to vulnerable sectors of society at affordable cost, payment in kind or the granting of scholarships according to the sectors or beneficiaries artistic and cultural training.

- Being a source of employment for the population for their activities is complex access a full-time job (young people, students, single mothers, housewives vulnerable sectors among others.)


Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Si no te es posible apoyarnos con donación en efectivo, nuestros requerimientos para llegar a la meta van mas aya, también nos hace falta equipo de audio para nuestros artistas invitados, equipo y menáge para servicio de restaurante, transportes para servicio a domicilio, transporte para compras de insumos, patrocinio para las subastas de la obra en exhibición y para nuestros artistas expositores, proyectores para las funciones y los talleres. Otra forma de apoyarnos y que es invaluable, es compartiendo nuestro proyecto en tus redes sociales, recuerda que entre mas personas se enteren de este loco sueño, mas posibilidades tenemos de tener éxito, así es que a compartir y comentar. Y recuerda que pronto te esperamos con el maridaje perfecto entre foro cultural y cocina de autor con extraordinarios artistas plásticos, músicos y la mejor cocina de autor al mejor precio, “Perra Hambre”

Other ways you can help

If you are unable to support us with cash donation, our requirements to reach the goal are more aya, we also need audio equipment for our guests, artists and household equipment for restaurant service, transport for home delivery, transportation input purchases, auctions sponsorship for the work on display and our exhibiting artists, headlights functions and workshops. Another way to support us and that is invaluable, is sharing our project in your social networks, remember that the more people become aware of this crazy dream, more likely we are to succeed, so to share and comment. And remember that soon we are waiting for the perfect marriage between cultural forum and cuisine with extraordinary artists, musicians and the best cuisine at the best price, "Perra Hambre"

story:
Collections: Birds Bones Butterflies by Leah Sobsey

The Book

I am honored to have been asked to publish a second book with Daylight Books distributed by D.A.P Distributed Art Publishers, release date, spring 2016. This campaign will help finance the creation of Collections: Birds Bones Butterflies, a hardback 128 page book of photographs with text by ornithologist John Fitzpatrick, Ph.D.and curator Xandra Eden. 


Birds from the North Carolina museum of Natural Sciences 


The What

Collections is a series of photographs of bird skins, bleached bones, tattered shoes and fragile butterflies that I have unearthed from the dark drawers of national park museum collections. Plucked from their original context, I illuminate them with sun and light, giving them new definition. The subject matter of each series I create is dictated by my discoveries, bridging past to present, honoring both the specimens I works with and the medium of photography.


Bones from the Everglades National Park


The Why

Collections is particularly timely during this centennial year of national parks service when climate change, and funding allocations for museums threaten indigenous species and artifacts into extinction. My focus on the parks is a way of preserving these fragile specimens that represent American history. This body of work sheds light on the importance and significance of the collections and their impact on science, history, the humanities and the hundreds of thousands of visitors – current and future – who leave their footprints on our national parks.


Handprinted Cyanotype Specimens


The Who

Fine art: My combined immersion in art and anthropology shaped my love of stories and gave me the tools to artfully map and investigate history -- my own and others. I primarily work in 19th century photographic processes intertwined with 21st century digital technology. In addition to my work being held in private and public collections across the country, I also exhibit nationally in galleries, museums and public spaces. 

Books and publications: I was one of the core photographers for Bull City Summer, along with Alec Soth, Hank Willis Thomas and Hiroshi Wantanabe, a collaborative documentary project that explores the Durham Bulls AAA baseball team. The book, published by Daylight Books, was released in 2014, and is one of their top sellers. My images have appeared in numerous publications including The New Yorker, the Paris Review Daily and Slate.com.

Community Art: Along with Lynn Bregman Blass, I am co-founder of the Visual History Collaborative.  We work with individuals, families, communities and organizations to create custom art through stories and artifacts– memories and mementos.

Educator: I received an MFA from the San Francisco Art Institute (where I also taught) and a BA in Anthropology and Sociology from Guilford College. I am a visiting assistant professor at the University of North Carolina, Greensboro,  North Carolina. I also teach at Duke University's Center for Documentary Studies and have also taught at the Maine Photographic Workshops. 

Shoes from Acadia National Park


Writers

Xandra Eden is Executive Director & Chief Curator of DiverseWorks in Houston. She was previously Curator of Exhibitions for the Weatherspoon Art Museum in Greensboro, NC. Since 2003, she has organized over 60 exhibitions of work by national and international contemporary artists. Recent major exhibitions include  Zones of Contention: After the Green Line  (2015);  Nancy Rubins: Drawing, Sculpture, Studies  (2014); and  Diana Al-Hadid  (2013). Eden held positions at the The Power Plant, Toronto, Canada, the Pollock-Krasner Foundation, New York, and Women & Their Work Gallery, Austin. She received her BFA from SUNY Purchase and MA from CCS at Bard College.

Dr. John Fitzpatrick is a native of St. Paul, Minnesota, graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University in 1974, and received his Ph.D. from Princeton University in 1978. Since 1995 he has been Director of the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology and professor in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at Cornell University. Previously (1988-1995), he was Executive Director of Archbold Biological Station, a private ecological research foundation in central Florida. From 1978 to 1989 he was Curator of Birds and Chairman of the Department of Zoology at Chicago’s Field Museum of Natural History. He is a Fellow of the American Ornithologists' Union, served as its President (2000-2002), and in 1985 received its highest research honor (Brewster Award) for his co-authored book Florida Scrub-Jay: Ecology and Demography of a Cooperative Breeding Bird. He has received numerous career awards for his work in science and conservation, including The Nature Conservancy, Linnaean Society of New York, Environmental Advocates of New York, and Audubon.

Book Details

Photographer: Leah Sobsey

Publisher: Daylight Books

Text: 

  • Leah Sobsey, Artist, Educator, Chapel Hill, NC
  • Xandra Eden, Executive Director and Chief Curator, Diverseworks Houston, TX
  • John W. Fitzpatrick, Phd, Director, Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Design: Ursula Damm

Size: 10"X10", hard cover, 128 pages

Retail Price: $45

Publication Date: April 2016 

What We Need

All of the funds raised here will go towards the production and publication of the photography book, Collections: Birds Bones Butterflies.

Still from the installation, Starlings

Text:

Xandra Eden, Executive Director and Chief Curator, Diverseworks Houston, TX
John W. Fitzpatrick, Phd, Director, Cornell Lab of Ornithology

Design: Ursula Damm
Size: 10"X10", hard cover, 128 pages
Retail Price: $45
Publication Date: April 2016 

What We Need All of the funds raised here will go towards the production and publication of the photography book, Collections: Birds Bones Butterflies.
Still from the installation, Starlings

story:
Introducing Central Saint Martins Architecture Degree Show

  • The degree show puts the best works of our course on public display, in an exhibition in the crossing of the Granary Building in King’s Cross 
  • It is an opportunity to show our work outside of the college, share ideas, learn from each other and inspire

 Help us raise the funds

  • The money will go to construction materials and tools, printing exhibition boards and catalogues, which will be available to take home throughout the duration of the exhibition. The exhibition will take place from 24th till 28th of June, in the crossing of the Granary Building in King’s Cross
  •  If we do not reach the goal, the money will still go to the show - every pound counts!

How it will help us

  • you will help us make a great exhibition of our work, on which we worked for the past year
  • the show offers an opportunity to showcase our projects outside of college and is often a place where architectural offices seek new talent, offering us a start into professional careers
  • it is an opportunity to showcase the architecture course at Central Saint Martins, share ideas and create a platform for debate about architecture today

story:
THE BASICS: THE RIDE TO CONQUER CANCER

This project is my way of helping to make a positive change in my neighbourhood and the world. 

This year I am raising money so I can participate in the Ride to Conquer Cancer.It's a ride in late August, from  Vancouver Canada to Seattle Washington... a 200+ km ride over 2 days. It is a great cause, and we all know someone directly affected by this disease. 

WHO AM I?

My name is Alex, I'm an artist living in Vancouver. 

I realize that I've been quite lucky in regards to my health, whatever challenges I've had stand in sharp contrast to the massive hardships that people with Cancer are confronted.  I want to use my health, my skill, and my energy to help those who struggle on a daily basis.  I am teamed up with a group called To The Max who are already raising funds for Cancer research and Cancer care.  (Check out their website here; http://tothemaxcycling.com) 

WHAT I'M DOING.


I need to raise $2,500 to participate in the Ride.  So far, I've raised $500 through my art projects, but it's time to make an effective push for the next $2,000

So I'll be producing custom-made poker-card boxes at Maker Labs in Vancouver. I'll even bring some boxes with me if you want to meet me at the finish line ; )

THE MONEY.

All profits will go towards my goal. I am asking for more than $2,500, as I need to cover the material costs.  Hopefully, with this project, I will exceed the $2,500 goal that is placed by the Ride To Conquer Cancer. 

The labour is my contribution. I calculate that it will cost me roughly $10 to produce each box, and part of the funds go to cover the admin fees involved with the campaign. I will not be profiting from this.


WHAT YOU GET. 

Besides satisfaction in donating to a good cause, you get something back as well. The main perk is a custom-made, laser-cut, hand-stained, baltic birch box that fits a standard deck of 52 playing cards. Hence, "Decking Cancer". It even has it's own living hinge built in (look it up on Wikipedia if you don't know what that is). What you end up with is a unique piece of art which is both functional and decorative. Larger contributions will receive unique pieces handcrafted by yours truly.  

THE PERKS.

$5 - I will send you a personal thank-you email

$10- I will give you a video shout-out by name during my bike training

$15- A single piece of stained baltic birch with a custom thank you message insert for you to proudly display. + Video shout out

$35- A full deck box with custom thank you insert. +Video shout-out (add $10 to add a custom image) 

$50- A full deck box, a To the Max t-shirt, video shout out (add $10 to add a custom image) 

$80- Two full deck boxes with a custom image, +video shout out. 

$200 - A full deck box with custom image and a Captain's Card (see below image #) with my signature, a t-shirt, + video shout out.  

$500 - Two full deck boxes with custom images, a t-shirt, a captain's card, a video shout out, and I will fly a little flag from my bicycle with your name on it during the ride. 

$2500 - Only available in Vancouver. I will take you out for a night on the town in Vancouver. You will also get 5 full deck boxes with custom images, 5 t-shirts, 2 captains cards, a video shout out, and a flag on my bicycle.  You are awesome. 


For the boxes; Shipping within Canada will be $13, within the United States $15 . Please add this to your Donation if you need to have it shipped.

 If you are in Vancouver, choose "Vancouver Victory" and I will personally deliver your perk on my bike (no charge). Shipping outside of Canada will be extra and determined at time of shipping.

IF WE DON'T REACH THE GOAL.

Sadly, not all campaigns make it. If this doesn't reach it's target, I won't be able to ride.

However, the main point here is to fundraise to overcome a major health issue that is responsible for 30% of all deaths in Canada (According to the Canadian Cancer Society.) 
So even if I don't ride… The profits will still go towards the B.C. Cancer Foundation.

CHALLENGES 

I could end up making a lot of boxes. Not the worst thing that could happen, and a few splinters are worth the cause.

SUMMING UP.

This is a large project, but it's for a good cause. 

If you get a kick out of this project, please share it with your friends.

Cheers!

—Alex Kennedy.

story:
The Project

How it all started...
 In 2007 I studied in India as part of a year-long, multi-country study abroad program called Rethinking Globalization. One afternoon I found myself sitting in a tent listening to a well-known local activist berate me and my classmates for our complicit role in what he called genocide - the thousands of farmer suicides committed every year, many of them by cotton farmers from the Vidarbha region. Every 30 minutes, a farmer in India, overwhelmed with debt, commits suicide. I was a consumer and citizen of the United States, a country that heavily subsidizes cotton, making the competition for non-US farmers next to impossible. Over the next few days I visited farms and heard several farmers tout Bt cotton, a genetically modified seed introduced by the St. Louis-based multi-national corporation, Monsanto. But these farmers who praised Bt had not seen an increase in productivity or profit, as was promised by Monsanto’s advertising. The contradiction that lies at the kernel of this encounter was the question that led me to return to India: Why do farmers promote the modernization of agriculture when it does not always serve their interests?

In 2011 I received a Fulbright research and language grant to spend a year working with cotton farmers and studying cotton farming in Maharashtra, India. A myriad of social, economic, and environmental factors play into this epidemic. In an effort to shed more light on this tragedy and gain a better understanding of the situation, I spent 7 months in Mulgavan, a village in central India that is primarily comprised of small-scale cotton farmers living below the poverty line. My research culminated with two projects: a body of photographs and blog posts documenting cotton farmers' experiences, and a narrative of a widow of a cotton farmer which was included in the Voice of Witness book Invisible Hands: Voices from the Global Economy. Through both of these projects I strive to take viewers beyond the statistics and consider the complexity of the lives of cotton farmers and their families.  I portray universal characteristics of humanity, hoping to, by doing so, narrow the gap between consumers of cotton and cotton farmers. Due to the time constraints my Fulbright and research visa, I had to leave India prior to the end of the cotton season and was unable to document the  final stages of the cotton season, including the harvest. My research felt incomplete, and although I had found two wonderful and creative outlets to share the work with audiences back in the US, I wanted to do more.

Since returning to St. Louis... 
I have timidly dreamt of creating some large-scale installation art piece that would play with the overwhelming number of farmer suicides in a way that had a more lasting and meaningful impact than hearing "Over 250,000 farmers have suicided…" My journals from the last few years are littered with questions like, How can I use cotton products like q-tips, tampons, t-shirts, bed sheets, gauze, etc. to represent the overwhelming number of Indian farmers that have taken their lives due to the pressures of debt that they've undertaken in order to grow cotton? Construct a large-scale noose made out of 250,000 necklines from cotton t-shirts? Can I do some sort of pop-up art at organizations/locations funded by Monsanto to shed light on their connection to this epidemic? 

I'm going back to India!...
This past spring I participated in a mini artist residency at the Yeyo Arts Collective and began to take steps to move from timidly dreaming out an art project to making it a reality. My work in the art community in St. Louis has opened up my process to be one that is more collaborative. This has inspired me to think of ways that I can work with cotton farmers that I met in India on this body of work, tentatively titled "100% cotton." The exact details of the forms that "100% cotton" can take are in progress. How the work unfolds is largely up to the farmers that I will be working with when I go back to India in October. I will be in India for all of October and most of November (7 weeks total) which includes the cotton harvest, the portion of the season that I missed in 2012. I'll be working on creating some art pieces with cotton farmers about their lives and their experiences as farmers.

What I Need & What You Get

Funding for... 
I received a grant from the Regional Arts Commission in St. Louis to help fund this project. I also recently won Sloup, a monthly soup dinner that crowdfunds arts and community impacts projects in St. Louis, MO. I'm quitting my job and committing all of my time to this project. While the funding from RAC and Sloup is enough to cover the basic bare-necessities of my project, I need additional funds to
  • cover costs of materials
  • extend the period during which I will have a translator helping me (my Marathi is a bit rusty!)
  • give myself a cushion for in-country expenses while in India
  • have time to work on finishing the project and installing in gallery(ies) when I return.

The $5,500 that I am aiming to raise with this Indiegogo campaign includes my funding needs as well as the cost of the Indiegogo fee, costs of printing/shipping for rewards, etc. Regardless of whether I reach my goal of raising $5,500, I will be going to India! The additional funding will help broaden the scope and possibility of the project and enable me to dedicate all of my time and energy to this project rather than, say, waiting tables!

Why does this even matter?
We all use cotton every day, whether it's in the t-shirt we're wearing, the kitchen towel we dry our dishes with, the cotton ball we take our makeup off with, the dollar bill we spend at the gas station… St. Louis is the home of Monsanto, which, like it or not, plays a role in this story. I feel that we all have a responsibility to know the far reaching impact of this multi-national corporation that prides itself in having such a positive impact on our city through its grant programs that support the arts and sciences.

This project is a meaningful opportunity for me to take a leap in my journey as an artist and build on past projects like a performance art piece I created in 2009 and a children's book I wrote and illustrated in 2010. It will allow me to continue my research on cotton farming and find more creative ways to bring the issues to audiences that might be, like I was in 2007, ignorantly complicit. At every step in this process I hope that my passion for this issue and my desire to use art to envision alternatives to the dire situation that cotton farmers are in shines through and that people like you are already learning something. With your help, I can have a wider impact and reach more people in more powerful ways!

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are hard... Money is tight... I get it! But there are several ways you can help out without getting your wallet out:

  • Share my project with your friends and family - maybe one of them can make a donation and the more people learning about this, the better!
  • Have an old t-shirt or something with cotton that you want to send me to incorporate in the work? Mail it to me!
    @ Aaron McMullin
    26590 Beltrees Road
    Godfrey, IL 62035

story:
Alberto Aguilar, Edra Soto and Christa Donner at the first Antiquarian Luncheon.

SHoP (Southside Hub of Production) was founded in 2010 by Laura Shaeffer, Mike Phillips and John Preus.  SHoP’s main aim is to stimulate local cultural activity and to foster artistic and cultural enrichment in the neighborhood, with the aim of reclaiming the commons and the networks of interdependency that create a fulfilling economy.


SHoP serves as a platform for artists young and old, writers, film-makers, craftspeople and educators and local civic organizations to gather and exchange resources and expertise, curate exhibits, host events and workshops, and provide space for local groups to meet.


SHoP Now:

In the spring of 2015, Top Studios, our former benefactor, invited SHoP to run the  project space in a beautiful storefront in Hyde Park, formerly occupied by the inspiring and beloved O'Gara and Wilson Antiquarian Bookstore.

Our vision for the current space is to set up a shared studio and production hall in the back, with makers units and tables for bookbinding, sewing and design, and self -publishing as well as other creative workshops and after-school arts activities. The studio would be well organized and flexible enough to accommodate events, film screenings and weekly salon nights as well to provide space for writer's groups, and other communities of practice.

The front display area would be used to showcase the objects made in the back production hall as well as provide space for self-published works from all over Chicago and beyond, feature editions and objects of interest and usefulness from local designers and, as well as objects of curiosity in keeping with the curatorial tradition of the former bookstore.

We plan to curate a series of large-scale exhibits that are participatory in nature, lasting 3 months each that would provide an atmosphere of reflection and community interest.

Since May of 2015, we have offered art classes to all ages; held film screenings, ran two intensive summer camps and hosted literary events and public forums on a variety of topics. Our first exhibit, curated by Jorge Lucero was The Barack Obama Presidential Library it opened June 5  and was featured in DNAInfo, the Sun-Times,  WTTW's Chicago Tonight local ABC news, and WBEZ, among other media. BOPL Press

Opening night of The Barack Obama Presidential Library, June 5, 2015.

Top Studios had committed to a three-year lease beginning this past May, but abruptly withdrew its funding in July.


We would like to continue to curate exhibits and offer shared studio space for workshops, performances and events that foster a sense of art and human possibility outside of existing commercial and institutional venues. But in order to achieve this we need your help.

We have been generously given a window of reduced rent allowing us to establish a proof of concept.  Due to Top Studios’ sudden financial withdrawal, we need to raise a minimum of $6,000 to cover operational costs and rent through the end of the calendar year, and $15,000 is our ultimate goal to stay beyond that time and invest in shared resources such as a large film screen, sound system, mic, tables, and rolling cabinets for our workshops and classes. We will continue to research grants and other forms of funding to help us become sustainable. Your donations are tax-deductible through our fiscal sponsor, the Resource Center, http://www.resourcecenterchicago.org/

Thank you for your time and continued support. All contributions are appreciated and we look forward to seeing you soon!

Thank you to all who have participated in SHoP projects, past, present, and future.

Artists Union diagram: main room with Incidental Chair Collection by John Preus. Photos by Lizzy Szwaya.

For two years, with support from the First Unitarian Church of Hyde Park and supporter and philanthropist Dr. Ken Schug, we were housed in a 16-room mansion in Hyde Park called the Fenn House. 

Photograph on the wall by Rachel Herman.

Red Flags family salon by John Preus and Kevin Reiswig. photo by Lizzy Szwaya.

After leaving the mansion at the end of our scheduled tenure there, we continued to program events and classes, and curate exhibits in other venues, one example is Ben Hecht's House Party, curated by Laura Shaeffer and Paul Durica: Ben Hecht's House Party.


Edra Soto hosts Happy Hours at the Antiquarian (housed inside the storefront).

Antiquarian Happy Hour: Tender: Edra Soto.

Antiquarian Luncheon. Jorge Lucero and Alberto Aguilar.

Alberto Aguilar, Edra Soto and Christa Donner at the first Antiquarian Luncheon.


A brief history of The Op Shop and SHoP

The Op Shop, the precursor project to SHoP, was initiated by Laura Shaeffer in 2009. Inspired by a long tradition of magical curiosity shops that have appeared for centuries in fiction and in real life, she imagined using some of the many vacant storefronts in Hyde Park on a temporary basis to create sites of independent cultural exchange. The Op Shop occupied four different storefront locations on 55th street between Lake Park and Cornell, at 53rd and Lake Park in Harper Court and finally at 53rd and Ellis,  before morphing into its next, more ambitious project: SHoP: the Southside Hub of Production. The Op Shop asked these questions: What do we have, what do we lack, and how do we use what we have to create the world we need?.

Op Shop 1, 2009. Window painting by Anders Nilsen: Swamp Trees. Photo by David Schalliol.

Op Shop 2, Adhocity, 2010: Cardboard signs leading the visitor around to the various projects of alternative and small-economy building, by Chris Lin and Kayce Bayer. Photo by Rachel Tredon.

Outside Op Shop 2 (in the old Hollywood Video store). Paul Durica's, " The Mystery of Al Capone's Vault" .

Op Shop 3, 30 Days/30 People: calendar of people and events. Photo by Rachel Tredon.

Mabel's Wayback Machine, by Kayce Bayer and Chris Lin.

Tango Milonga. Photo By Rachel Tredon

Op Shop 4, AgriCULTURE: Lia Rousset and Amber Ginsberg. Community potluck.

Community Potluck. Photo by Lizzy Szwaya

Thank you to all our past and current collaborators, volunteers and supportive fellow forward -thinkers and idealists. SHoP is nothing without the people who make it happen.
There are too many names to ever mention here, we are grateful to all!

A special thanks to our current core team:
Jeremy Cohen
Marrissa Coccaro
Thomas K Flynn
Candice Ralph
Kirsten Srinivasan: The Little SHoP of Writers


Thanks to our curators, participating artists and teachers:
Alberto Aguilar
Jim Duignan Stockyard Institute
Regin Igloria  North Branch Projects
Rebecca Keller: Adjunct Professor, Art History, Theory and Criticism
Art Education Sculpture
Ben Kodichek
Wilfried Kuehn http://kuehnmalvezzi.com/
Nitsana Lazerus
Jorge Lucero http://www.jorgelucero.com/Pages/default.aspx
Mike Phillips South Side Projections
Lavie Raven: University of Hip Hop
Bart Schulz: Executive Director, Civic Knowledge Project
Amy Sinclair
Hoyun Son
Norman Teague


Special thanks to Kione Konchi for her sweet drawings for our t-shirts and posters.
Thanks to Kevin Reiswig for building us beautiful  shelves to house our growing collection of self -published works.
Thanks to Marc Fischer, Brett Bloom and Ed Mar for allowing us to carry the wonderful booklets from Half Letter Press  and Temporary Services, and to Lumpen Times, Mash Tun and Proximity Magazine on commission and the generous help they have provided!
