story:
Hello to all the beautiful people who have taken the time to watch my video and scroll down to read this page. Thank you for the time you've already invested!

With your help

In October 2015, I will travel 4,000 miles to Chicago where I will travel to Detroit by bus. The journey will take us down to Detroit to meet with Detroit locals and artists/photographers who are currently investing time and energy and love and passion into a new vision of Detroit. In January 2016 I will fly, again by myself, to Chicago and travel down to Detroit to conclude the work after 8 months of collaboration and engaging with Detroit artists, musicians and innovators. The book will be printed and sent out to backers in April/May 2016.

I am going to be shooting images that will show Detroit as the inspiring hub of creativity that it is. Did you know that Detroit houses a park that is bigger than Central Park and is on an island between two countries?! And the Eastern Market that caters for 45,000 people each Saturday. Yes 45 THOUSAND! The Detroit institute of Arts beckons as it houses the 6th best art collection in the world. The architecture is something that should be celebrated, yes there are ruins everywhere but there is also the Guardian building, a 40-floor classic art deco skyscraper, the Fisher Building - built almost entirely out of marble and granite and the Grand Army of the Republic castle!


I'm a photographer, gaffer, film maker and visual artist.


A brain injury and broken back almost took my life in December of 2011. My injury has left me with a seriously diminished ability to retain memory or to multi task. In fact I was released from the care of the Brain Injury Rehabilitation Centre after more than three years of care and support just a few months ago and that was a huge and scary step for me. 

I have spent months talking to other artists and photographers and purveyors of positive action in Detroit and am super excited to meet all of them and see a side of Detroit that would be closed to me without these beautiful connections.

Just one example of the amazing connections that this work has made happen is the music on the video. During my last trip to Milwaukee I met some amazing creative people, whilst looking for music for this work one of my new wonderful friends from Milwaukee suggested this band Lights Alive who are from Chicago. After talking to Devon Carson about my work the band generously offered me use of this track which is just perfect for the project in Detroit. A million Thank You's to them for this! You can find them at LightsAlive.

If this campaign reaches £4,300 acclaimed photographer and videographer Lawrence Wheeler will be flying out with me in January and along with the footage that I take in July we will be making a short documentary film that we will enter into film festivals. All backers will be given the opportunity to see this film exclusively before it reaches the public domain!

Detroit is so well known for its demise, for its collapse and for its degradation and ruins but my photographs will be showing the inspiration, positivity and true grit soul of Detroit and will include the production of a gallery exhibition of photographs, a photo book, aerial photography and a lasting collaborative relationship between the London and Detroit Art scene.

WHY Detroit?

I see many parallels between my recovery and the beauty in Detroit. People love to dwell in negativity-it seems to be the human condition. I was told I might not walk again, I didn't believe it and here I am. Yes I was broken but now I am living my life albeit in a new way but life is AMAZING! And Detroit is home to a hub of positive and strong people who love their city for good reason.

I hope that my journey will inspire other people, especially survivors of TBI who are grappling with their own versions of a "new normal."

After my injury I never really lost faith that I would continue to explore the world with my camera. I still connect to the world through a camera – I just have a different perspective, a perspective that proves positivity and hope can be found in any situation.

Every day is therapy: Some days my hands shake too much to drive and photograph-on these days I edit. Some days editing takes me two or three times the amount of time it would have taken me before the injury-on these days I learn patience.

I’ve worked extraordinarily hard since my accident to not only recover physically but to relearn how to live daily life as a single mum to my two children, I had to relearn how to do the shopping, how to cook a meal and how to plan food for a week. 

Me and my children a year and a half after the accident.

I’ve been a photographer since I was 18 years old.  I was a busy working photographer at the time of the accident - a business that I ran with my very small son River often in a sling on my back during shoots.


                  

(I was in this brace 24 hours a day for 4 months before I started rehabilitation.)


This link is great for some medical information about traumatic brain injury.

After the injury my initial focus was on walking again, then on being able to deal with every day life by myself. It sounds simple but even making phone calls or writing a shopping list was enough to cause my brain to shut down resulting in psychogenic seizures for the first few years. I can’t do everything that I could do before the injury but I have overcome obstacles that I never would have thought I would encounter in my life.

This link is a great introduction to the effects of a brain injury and could be a good place to start for anyone looking for more information or support. Headway.

              

I am fiercely passionate about my freedom to be creative and about my right to live my life with a huge amount of positivity. These two desires are the reason I am still a photographer, film maker and artist today. With your support I can follow my dream to document a Detroit that is fighting back to live again with hope and creativity and through this I can inspire other survivors of brain injuries. 

My work really only stopped for a year or two, since the injury I have been back to Paris to photograph for some photo stories on culture, London and Milton Keynes for some work with youth and I have most recently spent time in Milwaukee, Wisconsin where I have started a body of work that will be ongoing for a few years and focuses on juxtaposing the visual state of disrepair  (Rust. Rust EVERYWHERE. Dilapidated houses. Bad Graffiti. Cars that are shot to bits...)  with the elevated scenes of pure beauty in landscape on the lake and finding joyous moments of humanity.

                     

                 

I have already financed;

A Nikon D810, A Nikon D90, A shift lens (for architectural photography), a 28mm lens, a 35-70mm lens, a 50mm lens and a 70-200mm lens, a specially designed kit bag, a few good tripods, a MacBook Pro, software and some GOOD WALKING SHOES! I have put all of my time and money into this project for many months now.

It is through the support of generous donors, voluntary help and sponsors that this journey will be possible. The funds raised through this campaign will be used to cover expenses for my flights from the UK, gas, a driver and a photo assistant for 21 days, plus a little towards food and lodging for the crew-we have some wonderful offers of accommodation in Detroit for the July part of the trip and I’m planning on eating as cheaply as possible in the spirit of supporting growth in Detroit. In reality the cost of the two trips could become pretty high, I am funding all equipment myself and am not taking a single penny for my time or work at any point over the next 8 months, so I am hoping for some in-kind donations to fill the gap. I know that this work is the beginning of something huge and I feel utterly blessed to be able to give my time and energy to this body of work. I’m truly excited to use my unique perspective as an English/Irish bred artist who has survived a traumatic injury and I’m honoured to be making this book of images showing Detroit as a city to look towards for emerging innovation and soulful belief in the Arts.

Any profits from the project will be donated to the Brain Injury Rehabilitation Centre in Bletchley, Milton Keynes which helps people  affected by Traumatic Brain Injury and Headway who are a national charity that provides support, services and information to brain injury survivors, their families and carers, as well as to professionals in the health and legal fields..

C'mon Universe, do your thing!

If you know anyone with connections to a national hotel chain, food franchise or rental car company, I'd love them to get in touch! In-kind donations and frequent flyer miles will be gratefully accepted. Also any charities or artists who would like to be involved in the images for the book, the exhibition images or in facilitating my relationship with an emerging Detroit spirit please do contact me!

What I still Need & What You Get;

Things your contributions will help with include:

-Starting funds to publish the book and get advance copies made.

-Payment for shoot assistant(s) - I will be employing photography students from Detroit to give them the benefit of my experience and hopefully some funds to help their education. I will be continuing to mentor them after the project is done.

-Gas Money for all the traveling to and within Detroit.

-Supplies, Prints, and possible space rental for exhibitions and the Book Release Party once it's been published.

-Design of the book by Brian Amey, a fabulous Graphic Designer with 15 years of experience.

-Chartered helicopter for aerial photography.

The goal: To raise £3,950 to really get this project off and running with the supplies needed to make it as great of a project as it can be (preliminary shooting has already begun and shoot dates are in place)

  • If I don’t reach my financial goal any proceeds that I do receive will be divided between basic financial costs and book production. Every perk will be honoured regardless of whether I meet the goal. If this campaign exceeds the goal there will be more money to donate at the end of the project and the book will be able to have high production values.
PERKS;

I am offering a ton of stuff ahead of public production time which is March/April 2016. The images that I send out will all be sent out in September of this year - 6 months before the book comes out! Obviously the signed prints of the cover image wont be sent out until the book has gone to print as we will all be deciding on that image together after shooting has finished in January.

Access to the blog will be via an email list where I will be writing several times a month, each week for some of the project. My writing is very honest, intimate and raw and will include the highest of the joyous moments and the stresses and frustrations that will inevitably be a part of this process. I will include technical specs wherever its appropriate and will literally take you along on the journey with me.

Every single person who backs this campaign will be included in the decision making for the cover image of the book and any other huge decisions that need to be made will go out as a vote. Every single backer will have the opportunity to help make the decisions about this book and the exhibition images.

For anyone who chooses the Skype consultations you can choose how to use your time with me, you can interview me on my work or my thought processes, you can use the time to ask me technical questions and have me help you to figure out how to tackle a shoot you are doing or you can use the time to talk to me about my experience with brain injury and life after brain injury. Its your time and you can choose how to invest it. You can also choose to have the Skype time in one hour long session or in two half an hour sessions (which would give you time to recompile your thoughts or practise any suggestions I might make).

If you choose to invest your donation in paying for a college student to work with me then you will surely have a massive karmic surge, I will use the money to cover all transport costs for then (meaning that none is unable to take up work experience due to lack of funds or transport) and I will feed them and buy them coffee. I will also be investing in the students that I work with. Not only will they get to spend a day with me and see my working practise (which is by far the quickest way to learn anything) but they will also sit with me while I edit and I will stay in touch with them after I leave Detroit in July and be on hand to answer questions they might have beforeI come back in January when they will have the chance to meet up with me again. I will happily help them with their personal work where I can. 

Risks & Challenges

The book design could take longer than scheduled, I am entirely basing my book cover image choice on a voting system that all of my backers will be a part of.

There are many challenges that I may face when coming to photograph any areas of decay in Detroit, the areas are dangerous, the situation in Detroit means that people make money where they can and that can include literally cutting out the metal work from the structures of buildings. I plan on doing most, if not all, of my urban exploring with local artists and residents who know the area well. I have done a lot of urban exploring here in England, navigating unsafe structures and have learned to do the unsafe things as safely as possible. As with everything in life there are risks and always will be - anything that can be done without a risk is not going to reap as rich a reward and I’m happy to take on board these risks. Telling this story is so important to me and making excellent images has been my life for a very long time now.

Artists are mercurial and while I have many liaisons lined up already I am very open to the willow like nature of life and if things change then I will change too. There is a steady stream of conscious artistic people who are open to connecting and sharing their view with me. All of this will be documented in the email updates.

Equipment could break. It happens - more than some people realise when you are taking on urban exploration. I have a second line of equipment and very good insurance. 

The whole project could be slowed down if I get caught with brain fog or other post brain injury symptoms like seizures (less likely as I know how to look after myself - but it could still happen) or if I (more likely) try to do too much too fast. I am ready for this, I deal with the symptoms every day of my life - dealing with it while I’m on this project will be much the same. If I do get caught up with symptoms I will take a little longer, simplify the way I’m doing things and tackle it gently, I will also be very honest about this in my updates.

Any amount will help make this project a success, not just for me, but for the students and local artists who make Detroit the amazing unbelievably creative place it has become by exposing a world of endless creativity and hope that some still don't even realize exists, even in their own hometown!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even Spreading the word about this project is VERY important and appreciated! So "Like" this page, link to it in your Facebook, Twitter, etc. Send emails, talk about the project! Anything to get the word out about the project is extremely helpful!!!

My injury has left me with a seriously diminished ability to retain memory or to multi task. In fact I was released from the care of the Brain Injury Rehabilitation Centre after more than three years of care and support just a few months ago and that was a huge and scary step for me. I have spent months talking to other artists and photographers and purveyors of positive action in Detroit and am super excited to meet all of them and see a side of Detroit that would be closed to me without these beautiful connections.Just one example of the amazing connections that this work has made happen is the music on the video. During my last trip to Milwaukee I met some amazing creative people, whilst looking for music for this work one of my new wonderful friends from Milwaukee suggested this band Lights Alive who are from Chicago. After talking to Devon Carson about my work the band generously offered me use of this track which is just perfect for the project in Detroit. A million Thank You's to them for this! You can find them at LightsAlive.If this campaign reaches £4,300 acclaimed photographer and videographer Lawrence Wheeler will be flying out with me in January and along with the footage that I take in July we will be making a short documentary film that we will enter into film festivals. All backers will be given the opportunity to see this film exclusively before it reaches the public domain!Detroit is so well known for its demise, for its collapse and for its degradation and ruins but my photographs will be showing the inspiration, positivity and true grit soul of Detroit and will include the production of a gallery exhibition of photographs, a photo book, aerial photography and a lasting collaborative relationship between the London and Detroit Art scene.WHY Detroit?I see many parallels between my recovery and the beauty in Detroit. People love to dwell in negativity-it seems to be the human condition. I was told I might not walk again, I didn't believe it and here I am. Yes I was broken but now I am living my life albeit in a new way but life is AMAZING! And Detroit is home to a hub of positive and strong people who love their city for good reason.I hope that my journey will inspire other people, especially survivors of TBI who are grappling with their own versions of a "new normal."After my injury I never really lost faith that I would continue to explore the world with my camera. I still connect to the world through a camera – I just have a different perspective, a perspective that proves positivity and hope can be found in any situation.Every day is therapy: Some days my hands shake too much to drive and photograph-on these days I edit. Some days editing takes me two or three times the amount of time it would have taken me before the injury-on these days I learn patience.I’ve worked extraordinarily hard since my accident to not only recover physically but to relearn how to live daily life as a single mum to my two children, I had to relearn how to do the shopping, how to cook a meal and how to plan food for a week. Me and my children a year and a half after the accident.


I’ve been a photographer since I was 18 years old.  I was a busy working photographer at the time of the accident - a business that I ran with my very small son River often in a sling on my back during shoots.



                  
(I was in this brace 24 hours a day for 4 months before I started rehabilitation.)

This link is great for some medical information about traumatic brain injury.
After the injury my initial focus was on walking again, then on being able to deal with every day life by myself. It sounds simple but even making phone calls or writing a shopping list was enough to cause my brain to shut down resulting in psychogenic seizures for the first few years. I can’t do everything that I could do before the injury but I have overcome obstacles that I never would have thought I would encounter in my life.
This link is a great introduction to the effects of a brain injury and could be a good place to start for anyone looking for more information or support. Headway.

              
I am fiercely passionate about my freedom to be creative and about my right to live my life with a huge amount of positivity. These two desires are the reason I am still a photographer, film maker and artist today. With your support I can follow my dream to document a Detroit that is fighting back to live again with hope and creativity and through this I can inspire other survivors of brain injuries. 
My work really only stopped for a year or two, since the injury I have been back to Paris to photograph for some photo stories on culture, London and Milton Keynes for some work with youth and I have most recently spent time in Milwaukee, Wisconsin where I have started a body of work that will be ongoing for a few years and focuses on juxtaposing the visual state of disrepair  (Rust. Rust EVERYWHERE. Dilapidated houses. Bad Graffiti. Cars that are shot to bits...)  with the elevated scenes of pure beauty in landscape on the lake and finding joyous moments of humanity.


                     
                 

I have already financed;

A Nikon D810, A Nikon D90, A shift lens (for architectural photography), a 28mm lens, a 35-70mm lens, a 50mm lens and a 70-200mm lens, a specially designed kit bag, a few good tripods, a MacBook Pro, software and some GOOD WALKING SHOES! I have put all of my time and money into this project for many months now.

It is through the support of generous donors, voluntary help and sponsors that this journey will be possible. The funds raised through this campaign will be used to cover expenses for my flights from the UK, gas, a driver and a photo assistant for 21 days, plus a little towards food and lodging for the crew-we have some wonderful offers of accommodation in Detroit for the July part of the trip and I’m planning on eating as cheaply as possible in the spirit of supporting growth in Detroit. In reality the cost of the two trips could become pretty high, I am funding all equipment myself and am not taking a single penny for my time or work at any point over the next 8 months, so I am hoping for some in-kind donations to fill the gap. I know that this work is the beginning of something huge and I feel utterly blessed to be able to give my time and energy to this body of work. I’m truly excited to use my unique perspective as an English/Irish bred artist who has survived a traumatic injury and I’m honoured to be making this book of images showing Detroit as a city to look towards for emerging innovation and soulful belief in the Arts.



Any profits from the project will be donated to the Brain Injury Rehabilitation Centre in Bletchley, Milton Keynes which helps people  affected by Traumatic Brain Injury and Headway who are a national charity that provides support, services and information to brain injury survivors, their families and carers, as well as to professionals in the health and legal fields..



C'mon Universe, do your thing!





If you know anyone with connections to a national hotel chain, food franchise or rental car company, I'd love them to get in touch! In-kind donations and frequent flyer miles will be gratefully accepted. Also any charities or artists who would like to be involved in the images for the book, the exhibition images or in facilitating my relationship with an emerging Detroit spirit please do contact me!



What I still Need & What You Get;



Things your contributions will help with include:

-Starting funds to publish the book and get advance copies made.


-Payment for shoot assistant(s) - I will be employing photography students from Detroit to give them the benefit of my experience and hopefully some funds to help their education. I will be continuing to mentor them after the project is done.






-Gas Money for all the traveling to and within Detroit.






-Supplies, Prints, and possible space rental for exhibitions and the Book Release Party once it's been published.
-Design of the book by Brian Amey, a fabulous Graphic Designer with 15 years of experience.
-Chartered helicopter for aerial photography.



The goal: To raise £3,950 to really get this project off and running with the supplies needed to make it as great of a project as it can be (preliminary shooting has already begun and shoot dates are in place)

If I don’t reach my financial goal any proceeds that I do receive will be divided between basic financial costs and book production. Every perk will be honoured regardless of whether I meet the goal. If this campaign exceeds the goal there will be more money to donate at the end of the project and the book will be able to have high production values.

PERKS;




I am offering a ton of stuff ahead of public production time which is March/April 2016. The images that I send out will all be sent out in September of this year - 6 months before the book comes out! Obviously the signed prints of the cover image wont be sent out until the book has gone to print as we will all be deciding on that image together after shooting has finished in January.
Access to the blog will be via an email list where I will be writing several times a month, each week for some of the project. My writing is very honest, intimate and raw and will include the highest of the joyous moments and the stresses and frustrations that will inevitably be a part of this process. I will include technical specs wherever its appropriate and will literally take you along on the journey with me.
Every single person who backs this campaign will be included in the decision making for the cover image of the book and any other huge decisions that need to be made will go out as a vote. Every single backer will have the opportunity to help make the decisions about this book and the exhibition images.
For anyone who chooses the Skype consultations you can choose how to use your time with me, you can interview me on my work or my thought processes, you can use the time to ask me technical questions and have me help you to figure out how to tackle a shoot you are doing or you can use the time to talk to me about my experience with brain injury and life after brain injury. Its your time and you can choose how to invest it. You can also choose to have the Skype time in one hour long session or in two half an hour sessions (which would give you time to recompile your thoughts or practise any suggestions I might make).
If you choose to invest your donation in paying for a college student to work with me then you will surely have a massive karmic surge, I will use the money to cover all transport costs for then (meaning that none is unable to take up work experience due to lack of funds or transport) and I will feed them and buy them coffee. I will also be investing in the students that I work with. Not only will they get to spend a day with me and see my working practise (which is by far the quickest way to learn anything) but they will also sit with me while I edit and I will stay in touch with them after I leave Detroit in July and be on hand to answer questions they might have beforeI come back in January when they will have the chance to meet up with me again. I will happily help them with their personal work where I can. 





Risks & Challenges


The book design could take longer than scheduled, I am entirely basing my book cover image choice on a voting system that all of my backers will be a part of.
There are many challenges that I may face when coming to photograph any areas of decay in Detroit, the areas are dangerous, the situation in Detroit means that people make money where they can and that can include literally cutting out the metal work from the structures of buildings. I plan on doing most, if not all, of my urban exploring with local artists and residents who know the area well. I have done a lot of urban exploring here in England, navigating unsafe structures and have learned to do the unsafe things as safely as possible. As with everything in life there are risks and always will be - anything that can be done without a risk is not going to reap as rich a reward and I’m happy to take on board these risks. Telling this story is so important to me and making excellent images has been my life for a very long time now.
Artists are mercurial and while I have many liaisons lined up already I am very open to the willow like nature of life and if things change then I will change too. There is a steady stream of conscious artistic people who are open to connecting and sharing their view with me. All of this will be documented in the email updates.
Equipment could break. It happens - more than some people realise when you are taking on urban exploration. I have a second line of equipment and very good insurance. 
The whole project could be slowed down if I get caught with brain fog or other post brain injury symptoms like seizures (less likely as I know how to look after myself - but it could still happen) or if I (more likely) try to do too much too fast. I am ready for this, I deal with the symptoms every day of my life - dealing with it while I’m on this project will be much the same. If I do get caught up with symptoms I will take a little longer, simplify the way I’m doing things and tackle it gently, I will also be very honest about this in my updates.





Any amount will help make this project a success, not just for me, but for the students and local artists who make Detroit the amazing unbelievably creative place it has become by exposing a world of endless creativity and hope that some still don't even realize exists, even in their own hometown!

Other Ways You Can Help






Even Spreading the word about this project is VERY important and appreciated! So "Like" this page, link to it in your Facebook, Twitter, etc. Send emails, talk about the project! Anything to get the word out about the project is extremely helpful!!!

story:
Short Summary

I've included a brief vocabulary section at the bottom!

I'm Rebekah Rosen, I'm a video game artist and recent college graduate. I've been making dolls for about a year now utilizing skills I learned in college (five years of 3D digital art experience as of 2015). 

Last year I went in search of a ball jointed doll (bjd) that was fat like me, and while I found hundreds of gorgeously sculpted dolls- they were all thin. I'm passionate about this project because I am not the only person out there seeking a doll with a bigger body type. I've received lots of positive reactions to my dolls and have at least 10 people that are serious about ordering one. I personally want this doll to shell one of my own characters who I've had since the mid 2000s!

Mature Face on BeechKiss Body!

Baby Face on BeechKiss Body!


What We Need & What You Get

  • Funding pays for:
  • Early prototypes (approximately $200 worth of 3D sls prints)
  • Full size MSD prototype (approx. $650 worth of 3D sls prints)
  • Casting estimate (approx. $2250 worth of resin casting fees) for 20 dolls [If goal is not met, I will downsize to an order of 10 dolls]
  • Shipping of prototype from the US to Korea for casting (unknown cost right now) by Haru
  • There are no other companies producing fat/plus size ball jointed dolls quite like mine. The few other plus size BJDs that exist are mostly YoSDs or tinies, or one of a kind (OoAK) original artist dolls (OADs). 
  • Most ball jointed dolls (bjds) are slim/thin, my dolls represent a breadth of bigger body types of which BeechKiss is the first, showing off an "apple" shape. This will be the first of my collectible resin bjds on the market and this is the first launch of being able to pre-order one of these dolls. 
  • There is also an option to get original artwork by me, which is customized for the individual of one of their own characters or dolls! And a desk figurine! And Jewelry!

Tiny Pygmy Hippo 3D Print

Stainless Steel Butterfly Key necklace


  • If I don't reach my goal I will still be getting the order of dolls, I just may need to down size how many dolls I order at first or will just find a way to pay the difference myself.
  • Doll Package comes with:
  • 1 set of 14mm eyes + eye putty (random color)
  • 1 original oakbottom doll bag
  • 1 original oakbottom pillow
  • 1 face protector
  • 1 Birth Certificate of Authenticity
  • 1 beginner doll care tips page
  • 1 handwritten thankyou note
  • 1 blank light skin ("normal" color) OR light tan color OR dark tan color OakBottom BeechKiss doll
The Impact
  • You'll get a doll that looks like you or one of your characters or maybe can make a new character around the doll!
  • Having dolls that show positive representations of bigger bodied people can help break down prejudicial barriers and help build the confidence of fat people that we are beautiful and natural.

Risks & Challenges

Overall BJDs are a hobby of waiting for customizable dolls, I am expecting a much faster turn around then is commonly had in the doll community so I expect many of you will be satisfied regardless of small delays.

  • It's possible the original prototype could be damaged in shipping to Korea, and may delay the process of getting her cast- but never fear, I can print replacement parts and go through the sanding, priming, and modifying stage again if needed.
  • It's possible the casting company may need to do some extreme modifications to get BeechKiss to be cast-able. This would also act as a small delay to production.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out and make some noise about OakBottom Dolls if you like what I do. 
  • Send me a message if you have any questions about my first doll or later dolls. 
  • If there's a doll you'd like to see that isn't out there- contact me and I can maybe make it for you (and 9 of your acquaintances)! 


Feel free to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Measurements:

-Height: 39cm
-Head: 17.5cm
-Eyes: 14mm
-Neck: 9.5cm
-Shoulder Width: 33cm (ish-)
-Arm Length (to tip of fingers): 18cm
-Chest:31cm
-Waist: 29cm
-Leg Length: 17cm
-Hips: 34.5cm
-Ankle: 6cm
-Foot Length: 6cm


A Note About Layaway

I have added the first layaway payment to the campaign- The other two payments are due via paypal invoices and the third will include the shipping. You have until January 2016 to complete your layaway payments. Be sure to let me know which head you want (baby face or mature face) and be sure to select the skin tone you want/ for the tan option whether you want dark or light tan.


Vocab:

BJD(s) - ball jointed doll(s)

shell - customizing a doll to look like one of your original characters

face up - customizing the face of a doll

blushing - adding pigment to areas where there is increased blood flow in living creatures onto a doll, especially the face and joints

blank - the doll has no customizing paint such as a face up or blushing

resin - a type of smooth plastic

MSD - 1/4 human scale doll (BeechKiss is this size!)

SD - 1/3 human scale doll (BeechKiss is not this size.)

YoSD - 1/6 human scale doll (BeechKiss is not this size.) 

OC(s) - original character(s)

sls - selective laser sintering from wikipedia: "is an additive manufacturing (AM) technique that uses a laser as the power source to sinter powdered material (typically metal), aiming the laser automatically at points in space defined by a 3D model, binding the material together to create a solid structure."

Why does tan skin cost more than light skin?

Answer: Tan skin is harder to make and the pigment is probably more expensive. Note: Tan skin colors will always show a little bit of the seams on the doll and this is not considered a defect.

Image from Haru Casting's tumblr:  http://harucasting.tumblr.com


Digital Portrait Painting Samples:


Sketch Samples:

story: Over the past four years we have self produced this event that has been a very successful one. This year, we tremendously need your help. This very first funding campaign for this festival like event needs your support in order to afford production costs which include theater rental, and sound and light equipment.

This very first funding campaign for this festival like event needs your support in order to afford production costs which include theater rental, and sound and light equipment.

story:
The Dwntwn Arts Fair

A family-friendly street fair filled with art, music, crafts, and comedy, the Dwntwn Arts Fair is truly a cultural showcase that everyone will enjoy. Brought to you by a team of grassroots organizations with strong ties throughout our local community, our goal is to foster the growth of all the different artistic elements that make up our cities culture.

Part of DWNTWN Art Days
Produced by Life Is Art in partnership with Buskerfest, Kondoit, YO Miami, Indiegals, Celebrate Diversity Miami and Elwoods Gastro Pub with the support of the Downtown Development Authority, Downtown Miami Partnership, and sponsored by the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau and Miami Herald.

EVENT DETAILS
DATE: September 12 - 13, 2015
TIME: Saturday 12:00pm - 10:00pm,
Sunday 12:00pm - 8:00pm
LOCATION: NE 3rd Avenue between NE 1st and 2nd Street, Downtown Miami, FL
The show is free and open to the public.

EVENT HIGHLIGHTS:
* An art exhibition of local artists curated by Life Is Art.
* Live music and performances organized by Buskerfest
* Muralists brought by Kondoit to enhance downtown.
* Local urban artists and live painting showcase by YOMiami.
* Celebrate Diversity Miami photo-voice exhibit and participatory activities.
* FoodSpark social-issues brainstorming meal.
* A wearable art and craft show by Indiegals.
* A skyscape installation by Elwoods Gastro Pub.
* Food and drink specials by local participating restaurants.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $4700 to help cover the costs of the production of a nice show. This covers things like tents, police security, barricades and signage, electricity, insurance and other infrastructure (all the boring stuff that makes these events happen). Any additional money will go for more live performances, as well as enhancements to the infrastructure.

As a thank you to our donors, we have enlisted the talented Aquarela Sabol to create a special piece of art for the event. From her work, we are making some exclusive merchandise just for our donors, including stickers, posters, t-shirts and even signed, limited edition prints. This will be the ONLY place you will be able to get this exclusive merchandise, it will not be for sale at the event or anytime afterwards. We are also offering special thank you posts on our websites and social media. In addition, we have artist booth spaces and larger sponsorship packages available, up to and including having the event named after you!

Artists

If you would like to exhibit at the show, please choose the $100 "Artists Booth" option. This is ONLY available to artists located in South Florida. We encourage you to split the booth with one or more artists. Each booth space is 10x10 and comes with a pavilion tent and electricity. You will need to bring all your own display materials, easels, tables, chairs, lights, etc. All products sold in artist booths must be made from original work by the artists, but may include prints, t-shirts and other merchandise. See this link for the fine print.

Sponsors

For details on all the benefits available to each sponsorship level, please click here.

The Impact

We are creating the Dwntwn Arts Fair in order to allow more artists and organization participate in the big DWNTWN Art Days that is produced by the Downtown Development Authority and includes dozens of arts organizations located around Downtown Miami. By creating a pop-up street festival, we create a temporary space where artists and organizations that may not be located in downtown can take advantage of the massive media coverage surrounding the exciting weekend.

In addition, a family-friendly street festival engages the community in a special way. By placing art in the public space, we create an opportunity for residents to accidentally encounter culture and culture builds communities.

Life Is Art has over a six year track record of creating wonderfully engaging events designed to bring the community together around local art. We have produced well over one-hundred events of all shapes and sizes. For this show, we have teamed up with some other exciting organizations who bring their own unique experience to the programming.

Risks & Challenges

Of course, as any outdoor event in South Florida, we face weather challenges; however, we have never let that stop us in the past. We have tents for all the artists and programs. Should it get too bad, we can adjourn to the numerous restaurants along the street with whom we are partnering.

Other Ways You Can Help

We can definitely use some volunteers, especially to help set up Saturday morning and clean up Sunday night. Just fill out this form and mention you want to help with Dwntwn Arts Fair!

Of course, we would love if you can help promote our fundraiser. Use those Indiegogo share tools to let your friends know.

Social Media
Life Is Art: Website, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram
Soul Of Miami, Website, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram
Buskerfest Miami, Website, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram
Yo Miami, Website, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram
Indiegals, Website, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram
Pangea Galleria, Website, Facebook
Kondoit, Website
Celebrate Diversity Miami, Website, Facebook, Twitter

  Aquarela Sabol to create 
  a special piece of art for the event. From her work, we are making some exclusive 
  merchandise just for our donors, including stickers, posters, t-shirts and even 
  signed, limited edition prints. This will be the ONLY place you will be able 
  to get this exclusive merchandise, it will not be for sale at the event or anytime 
  afterwards. We are also offering special thank you posts on our websites and 
  social media. In addition, we have artist booth spaces and larger sponsorship 
  packages available, up to and including having the event named after you!
Artists
If you would like to exhibit at the show, please choose the $100 "Artists 
  Booth" option. This is ONLY available to artists located in South 
  Florida. We encourage you to split the booth with one or more artists. Each 
  booth space is 10x10 and comes with a pavilion tent and electricity. You will 
  need to bring all your own display materials, easels, tables, chairs, lights, 
  etc. All products sold in artist booths must be made from original work by the 
  artists, but may include prints, t-shirts and other merchandise. See this link for the fine print.
Sponsors
For details on all the benefits available to each sponsorship level, 
  please click here.
The Impact
We are creating the Dwntwn Arts Fair in order to allow more artists and organization 
  participate in the big DWNTWN Art Days that is produced by the Downtown Development 
  Authority and includes dozens of arts organizations located around Downtown 
  Miami. By creating a pop-up street festival, we create a temporary space where 
  artists and organizations that may not be located in downtown can take advantage 
  of the massive media coverage surrounding the exciting weekend.
In addition, a family-friendly street festival engages the community in a special 
  way. By placing art in the public space, we create an opportunity for residents 
  to accidentally encounter culture and culture builds communities.
Life Is Art has over a six year track record of creating wonderfully engaging 
  events designed to bring the community together around local art. We have produced 
  well over one-hundred events of all shapes and sizes. For this show, we have 
  teamed up with some other exciting organizations who bring their own unique 
  experience to the programming.
Risks & Challenges
 Of course, as any outdoor event in South Florida, we face weather challenges; 
    however, we have never let that stop us in the past. We have tents for all the artists 
    and programs. Should it get too bad, we can adjourn to the numerous restaurants 
    along the street with whom we are partnering.
Other Ways You Can Help
We can definitely use some volunteers, 
    especially to help set up Saturday morning and clean up Sunday night. Just 
    fill out this 
    form and mention you want to help with Dwntwn Arts Fair!
Of course, we would love if you can help promote our fundraiser. Use those 
    Indiegogo share tools to let your friends know.
Social Media
    Life Is Art: Website, 
    Facebook, 
    Twitter, Instagram
    Soul Of Miami, Website, 
    Facebook, Twitter, 
    Instagram
    Buskerfest Miami, Website, 
    Facebook, 
    Twitter, 
    Instagram
    Yo Miami, Website, Facebook, 
    Twitter, Instagram
    Indiegals, Website, Facebook, 
    Twitter, Instagram
    Pangea Galleria, Website, 
    Facebook
    Kondoit, Website
    Celebrate Diversity Miami, Website, 
    Facebook, 
    Twitter

story:
Για Ελληνικά, πιο κάτω!!!

Hello!

I am Christos Modestou, a 26 year-old musician!

My dream is to create a place where artists can exhibit their work, stage theatrical performances, and organize music events.

My obstacle in fulfilling this dream is the crisis. The dreams of thousands of young people have sunk, the same way as the Greek economy has. Banks don't give loans, families can't help...

The power of culture, arts, literature and everything that cultivates our soul is what can simply fight against the financial crisis.

What I'm trying to do is to build a place where we can create music, drama and poetry nights. This center will also host exhibitions of paintings and handmade jewelry!So, I have decided to gather some money in order to set up this center.

I have asked my friend, Andreas Moyseos, an artist, to find inspiration by creating something small starting from the name of this center, " GiocondArt ". The smile of Mona Lisa, full of love and optimism,invites us to move forward towards our goal in these difficult days we are living!

This is how we came to the final result: asketchof the perhaps most famous work of art in the world! This sketch, in limited copies, is what we are offering you! It comes in two formats: oncardboard and on T-shirts. These copies arehand-made, by screen printing.This is an age-old way of copying, behind which lies an entire ceremony!


Apart from the choice of printed T-shirts and cardboard, there is also the option to pre-buy your coffee or your drink. If you prefer, you could simply contribute by donating!

I would be grateful for your help.

I am hopeful that art and culture will appeal to people’s hearts!

Yours sincerely,

Christos Modestou



Γειά σας!

Είμαι ο Χρίστος Μοδέστου, και είμαι ένας 26χρονος μουσικός!

Το όνειρο μου είναι να φτιάξω έναν χώρο για καλλιτέχνες όπου μπορούν να εκθέσουν έργα τους, να ανεβάσουν θεατρικές παραστάσεις, να κάνουν μουσικές βραδιές.

Εμπόδιο σε όλο αυτό έχει μπει η κρίση. Τα όνειρα χιλιάδων νέων έχουν βυθιστεί, όπως βυθίστηκε και η Ελληνική οικονομία. Οι τράπεζες δεν δίνουν δάνεια, οι οικογένειες δεν μπορούν να βοηθήσουν.

Το όπλο ενάντια στην κρίση είναι ο πολιτισμός, οι τέχνες, τα γράμματα, είναι η καλλιέργεια της ψυχής μας!!!!

Αυτό προσπαθώ να κάνω. Να δημιουργήσω έναν χώρο που θα γίνονται μουσικές, θεατρικές, ποιητικές βραδιές. Εκθέσεις ζωγραφικής, χειροποίητων κοσμημάτων!

Με αυτόν τον τρόπο, αποφάσισα να μαζέψω κάποια λεφτά για τα δημιουργία αυτού του χώρου.

Ζήτησα από τον φίλο μου Ανδρέα Μωυσέως, ζωγράφο, να εμπνευστεί κάτι μικρό από το όνομα του χώρου, “GiocondArt”. Το χαμόγελο της Μόνα Λίζα, γεμάτο αγάπη και αισιοδοξία, μας καλεί να πορευτούμε προς τον στόχο μας τις δύσκολες αυτές μέρες που διανύουμε!

Έτσι βγήκε το αποτέλεσμα! Ένα σκίτσο του διασημότερου ίσως έργου στον κόσμο! Αυτό το σκίτσο, σε περιορισμένα αντίτυπα το προσφέρουμε σε σας! Σε δύο μορφές. Σε χαρτόνι και σε φανέλα. Τα αντίγραφα αυτά, έγιναν με μεταξοτυπία στο χέρι. Έναν πανάρχαιο τρόπο αντιγραφής, που κρύβει πίσω του μια ολόκληρη ιεροτελεστία!


Εκτός από την επιλογή της φανέλας και του πίνακα, υπάρχει και η επιλογή να προ-αγοράσεις τον καφέ ή το ποτό σου. Ή αν θες μπορείς απλά να βοηθήσεις με μια εισφορά!


Αναμένω στην βοήθειά σας.

Ελπίζω στην αγάπη του κόσμου στην τέχνη και τον πολιτισμό!

Σας ευχαριστώ,

Χρίστος Μοδέστου

story:
Hello friends of the pirate ship!  I am teaming up with the creator and owner of the pirate ship, Gary Ramsbottom, to help rescue the  'Obsidian'.  Gary and I have collaborated on a number of projects and films.  We've arranged it so the funds go to Gary, as creator and builder of the ship, to manage the project and rescue of the 'Obisidian'.  We'll also be documenting the progress of the ship's rescue and recovery. Gary knows the ship inside and out so I'll let him explain.  
- Peter Schramm


Hello friends of the pirate ship 'Obsidian', my name is Gary Ramsbottom,
The pirate ship 'Obsidian' began it's life as a wooden, single masted
sailboat (circa 1920).  I bought it and after much work made it float. Then I
built the top-side, and all the piratey bits. It has been moored on Kootenay
Lake in Nelson for five years.

I am the builder and owner of the pirate ship. I've been creating art for
almost fifty years, painting, drawing, sculpting, writing, film and video,
music and building cool things like castles and pirate ships.
I have lived in the Nelson area for almost thirty years.

Recently the pirate ship sank and needs to be rescued. It has become a
local icon, attracting locals and tourists alike. Of course children think it's the greatest.
There is a sense of pride around it locally, like "look what we can do".
It is used by some local business' in their advertising. The pirate ship has
appeared in Maclean's magazine, wooden boat.com chat room, on television and
radio, many newspaper articles and such.
If you go to http://www.placestosee.macleans.ca/
(article "(article "Canada 2014:  10 places you've got to see)

and click on "Nelson", you will see majestic Kootenay Lake with the pirate ship in it. 

Here are some links to articles in the Nelson Star newpaper on the previous repair of the ship:
http://www.nelsonstar.com/news/271308341.html
and her most recent sinking:
http://www.nelsonstar.com/news/321928541.html

If we don't reach our goal the funds raised will go to raising the pirate ship
and whatever repairs we can manage. The rescue of the pirate ship will mean
a lot to the people of Nelson, especially the children, who always ask their
parents to go see it whenever shopping at the nearby mall.

Nelson is also a well known arts center and the arts community see it as a
delightful piece of art. Businesses like it because it's an attraction for
visitors, some of them come to Nelson specifically to see it. Thousands upon
thousands of photos have been taken.

To raise 'Obsidian' we need to hire a big barge with a crane to lift her
right out of the water for dry docking. Cost of the barge, other gear and
probably a diver will be approximately $2,500, the balance will go into
redoing the hull, the whole upper side of the boat needs to be rebuilt,
new ropes, miscellaneous decorative bits and lots of other small details.
We may have to pay for rent or storage also while work is being done.

I have lots of experience working on other projects such as feature films,
short films and feature documentaries, scripts, hundreds of paintings, and
a castle. I was a founding director of a film co-operative and an arts
collective. I am project oriented as an artist and a builder, solving
challenges by pre-planning and in the moment brainstorming. I enjoy
challenges and relish the moment when a project is completed.

If you would like to help in ways other than with money you can spread the
word about the crowd funding, or if you are local, we will be gathering for
work parties and such.


Thank you, Gary Ramsbottom.

story:
Reading "Jitterbug Perfume" catapulted a dream where I can now create art within a business context and make perfumes that help people feel good. 

The creative process is all about interpreting sounds, timbre, pitch, harmonies, melodies, tone and tempo into perfume. Wearing these perfumes is all about changing your perception of yourself and others. 

It's all for art, from the heart. 


What's the project?

This indiegogo campaign will help me purchase the supplies necessary for a new perfume that I have created. The concept is ready, the formula is ready, the artwork is ready. All the supplies just need to be ordered and put into production. 
The idea behind the perfume is sweet and genuine. It contains notes of ginger, turmeric, osmanthus, benzoin, castoreum and musk. It is meant to be worn by both men and women, letting the skin tell the rest of the story. I have been working on the perfume for a year and a half and have already tested it on many different skin types and colours. 
There are no parabens or additional chemicals added. It's raw materials, alcohol to dilute, straight to the bottle. 

Where will the funds go?

Supplies include:
  • Raw Materials (wait till you smell this stuff.... sooo good)
  • Bottles 
  • Boxes 
  • Marketing (social media, photography) 
I would also like to better equip the lab so as to be able to produce larger batches. This requires the purchasing of:
  • Scales 
  • Beakers
  • Funnels
  • Filters
Overall, your contributions will help my business grow exponentially.


What's in it for you?

  • All the perks to the right are all handmade. (sent out by December approx) -->
  • Each perfume has been created and thought out, hand poured, as well as labeled and boxed individually. 
  • The mix tapes (vintage cassette tapes) are hand painted with alcohol ink and each piece is beautifully unique...throwback!


Why is this project worth supporting?

1. Let's face it, there aren't a lot of scent/olfactory related projects out there. 

2. Scent & Music...what?! Cool! Let's take things to the next level. Being conscious of our senses and how they work together helps us look at our world differently. Why aren't we focusing on poly sensory experiences more?

3.  The connection between scent & sound can be replicated and appreciated at concerts and at art exhibits.    (think of the extensions!)

4. Using our sense of smell more consciously, being aware of it's role in our day-to-day.

5. Your contribution will not only be helping create a new perfume, it will help set in motion more projects. Some of which include: 

  • Cross-genre collaborations
  • Scented Concerts (hello musicians!)
  • Exploring different forms & structures of music for future perfume collections
  • A multi sensory children's book inspired by the senses. 


Risks & Challenges

Time.  I would like to launch in time for the holiday season. If this isn't possible, I will work on it during the winter and the perfume will come to fruition in the spring.


Want to help but can't?

I get it, I've been there...but I've always learned that there's something special in spreading the word. If you agree, your support is madly appreciated!

Tweet: "Support artisan perfumery & olfactory art, @thescentinel has launched an @Indiegogo campaign http://igg.me/at/jazminsarai  "

Share by email: 

http://igg.me/at/jazminsarai

Like the "Parfums Jazmin Sarai" page on Facebook. 

Follow us on Instagram. 

Read up if you want to know what's been accomplished so far. 

www.jazminsarai.com

and a sincere THANK YOU!!

story:
Guapamacataro Artist Residency

My name is Stephanie Gonzalez. I am a performance artist from the Midwest, a recent graduate from the University of Northern Iowa and I am now beginning my career in the Arts! I'm very thrilled and honored to have been selected to participate in a 24 day residency in Michoacan, Mexico. This residency is an immense opportunity for me as an artist to be in an environment and have the time to create work. I am originally from Mexico and this opportunity would allow me to reconnect with my roots. With your help, I will be able to make my way down to Michoacan and participate in this residency which will help me evolve personally and professionally. This opportunity will help me fuel new work and help me focus on my concepts of Identity politics and its relationship to the Cosmos (spacetime, theory of relativity). 

I am hoping to raise $1500 

This will go towards the following:


What I Need & What You Get

I need your HELP!

I am hoping to raise $1500 

This will go towards the following:

  • Cost of the Residency (food and accommodations) 
  • Flight and travel
  • Art supplies

Don't Worry, there's PERKS if you pledge!!

  • A pledge of $25 will get you a small piece of work (photograph, page from my sketchbook, piece of poetry)
  • A pledge of $75 or more will get you the option of a photograph or link to a performance dedicated to you personally!  
  •  A pledge of $100 or more will get you both a photograph and link to a performance dedicated to you personally!

The Impact

This means ALOT to me! I'm passionate about making work and am honored and thrilled to be given this opportunity. This is a great way to jumpstart my career as an artist and it is even more immense that I will be doing this in Mexico, a place where I grew up and is close to me. The culture and surroundings will push me and my work in ways that are yet to be discovered, this is why I MUST do this! 
Being in Mexico will allow me to continue to explore my work with Identity politics: a universal topic that everyone can associate with; who are you, where are you from, how has your past shaped you, how does your present affect you, and how does the future perceive you? I want to begin to tie this concept with ideas of the cosmos and spacetime; where do we, as individuals fit in our ever expanding universe?
Big themes call for time, dedication, and a lot of work. This opportunity will allow me to begin this life work.


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please feel free to share this with friends and family and help me get the word out!
THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU!
 A big Thank you to Justin A. and Lucas W. for your help shooting!

http://www.estephaniagonzalez.com/
http://guapamacataro.org/
story_txt:
Guapamacataro Artist Residency My name is Stephanie Gonzalez. I am a performance artist from the Midwest, a recent graduate from the University of Northern Iowa and I am now beginning my career in the Arts! I'm very thrilled and honored to have been selected to participate in a 24 day residency in Michoacan, Mexico. This residency is an immense opportunity for me as an artist to be in an environment and have the time to create work. I am originally from Mexico and this opportunity would allow me to reconnect with my roots. With your help, I will be able to make my way down to Michoacan and participate in this residency which will help me evolve personally and professionally. This opportunity will help me fuel new work and help me focus on my concepts of Identity politics and its relationship to the Cosmos (spacetime, theory of relativity). 
I am hoping to raise $1500 
This will go towards the following:
   What I Need & What You Get
I need your HELP!

I am hoping to raise $1500 
This will go towards the following:


Cost of the Residency (food and accommodations) 
Flight and travel
Art supplies


Don't Worry, there's PERKS if you pledge!!

A pledge of $25 will get you a small piece of work (photograph, page from my sketchbook, piece of poetry)
A pledge of $75 or more will get you the option of a photograph or link to a performance dedicated to you personally!  
 A pledge of $100 or more will get you both a photograph and link to a performance dedicated to you personally!    The Impact
This means ALOT to me! I'm passionate about making work and am honored and thrilled to be given this opportunity. This is a great way to jumpstart my career as an artist and it is even more immense that I will be doing this in Mexico, a place where I grew up and is close to me. The culture and surroundings will push me and my work in ways that are yet to be discovered, this is why I MUST do this! 
Being in Mexico will allow me to continue to explore my work with Identity politics: a universal topic that everyone can associate with; who are you, where are you from, how has your past shaped you, how does your present affect you, and how does the future perceive you? I want to begin to tie this concept with ideas of the cosmos and spacetime; where do we, as individuals fit in our ever expanding universe?
Big themes call for time, dedication, and a lot of work. This opportunity will allow me to begin this life work.   
    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:  Please feel free to share this with friends and family and help me get the word out! 
THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU!
 A big Thank you to Justin A. and Lucas W. for your help shooting!


http://www.estephaniagonzalez.com/


http://guapamacataro.org/

story:
We are building a 30-foot long American Bison to roam the Playa at Burning Man 2016!

Kindred Spirit will be 30-feet of audio-visual stimulation designed to spark conversation about the American Bison's complicated past, present, and future. Our art car will provide a lens through which we can explore the majestic mammal that's an intrinsic part of our collective history.

Our baby will be visually stunning, with a brown fur base meant to mimic the real animal by day, then glowing in a custom overlaid geometric color-changing LED pattern by night. Our furry sound-stage will host artist, live musician, and DJ performances throughout the week, and will feature an upper deck to dance, lounge, and catch great views of the Playa!

Millions of bison once grazed the continent, serving as a major resource for the people who lived here for centuries. As ranching, farming, and mass hunting expanded in the 17-1800's, the bison's natural habitat became increasingly compromised. At the turn of the twentieth century and after decades of near-extermination, fewer than 1,000 bison remained alive. Through conservation and re-population efforts, there are now around 500,000 bison in North America, including some in Nevada. Very few of these animals, however, are cut from the same genetically-pure, free-ranging cloth of their ancestors. President Obama just signed a bill making the American Bison our official "national mammal!" 

How we're bringing Kindred Spirit to life...

Our flatbed truck is being transformed into a two level mutant vehicle. The ground level will feature all of Kindred Spirit's inner workings, and the upper deck will be open to anyone and everyone to enjoy!

Kindred Spirit's centerpiece will be an 11 feet high, 8 feet wide custom-designed steel bison's head, mounted to the front of our vehicle and visible from far away. Custom-built 3D panels will be mounted along the sides of the vehicle, creating the bison's shoulders, back, and hips. The panels will all be covered in different shades and lengths of brown fur to mimic those of a bison.

The entire vehicle will be covered in a geometric lighting pattern. The head and each of the above-mentioned panels will have individually addressable LED light strips pre-installed, creating an endless number of visual pattern possibilities.

The upper deck will be illuminated by a combination of par can lights, blacklights, and more LED strips.

We'll be bumpin' beats late into the night through our finely tuned sound system. It will be elevated between 3 and 11 feet off the ground, creating a top quality music experience for all desert dwellers. The upper deck will also feature its own sound set-up.

Kindred Spirit is a collaboration between a bunch of different crews...we would absolutely love and appreciate your help to make it happen!


Here's where your help will go...

We have spent the last eight months conceptualizing, designing, and funding our creation. All of the pieces are in place to execute on every aspect, and your contributions are directly helping us cross the finish line and deliver our gift to the Playa...

Metalwork: The major metalwork is happening at Metal Inc in Philadelphia. They've done awesome work for several other art cars on the Playa. For Kindred Spirit, they are building our storage room (where generators, subwoofers, cabling, etc will be housed), internal stairwell, upper deck, railings, DJ booth, and many other details. It's a massive undertaking, and we're grateful that Metal Inc is taking on a huge part of the project.

Bison head: We've teamed up with Ian Liljeblad to construct our centerpiece, the Bison head that will cover the front of the vehicle. Ian is the man behind the famous reggae-inspired Movement of Jah People art car. His metal fabrication work is fantastic, and we couldn't be happier to have him on board.

Lighting: Our in-house design team is busy mapping our LED strips to fit the bison's head and body. They are also meticulously writing lines of computer code so we can melt as many faces as possible. We've figured out exactly how many strips + components we need, and your donations will help us unlock higher levels of visual stimulation. 

Transportation: It's gonna be quite the journey to get KS from New York City to Black Rock City.  The rear storage room will house all of our gear, eliminating the need for additional vehicles, but the cross-country trip won't be free!

Everything you contribute will be distributed to these crucial elements of Kindred Spirit's existence!


Fun perks!

Aside from limitless on-Playa debauchery, your contributions will get you some awesome perks:

Stickers - Stylize with a Kindred Spirit sticker featuring our Bison head logo and Burning Man 2016 insignia. It looks good on anything!

Stainless Steel Bottles - Stay hydrated on the Playa (and in the default world) with a custom-printed Kindred Spirit logo stainless steel water bottle!

T-Shirts - Show your Bison-inspired pride in a fresh Kindred Spirit t-shirt. The front features our Bison head logo, and the back has the words "Kindred Spirit" printed between the shoulders.

Hoodies - Stay warm and fuzzy on the Playa or at home in our Kindred Spirit hoodie! It features our Bison head logo on the front.

Pendants - Look your absolute Playa freshest with our customized Kindred Spirit logo pendants. These are hand-crafted pieces that will look great on a chain or as a stand-alone pendant.

Kindred Spirit's Impact...

Burning Man 2016 is the first phase of a long-term plan for Kindred Spirit. We hope our time on the Playa this year will put smiles on your faces and that we'll watch the sunrise on our upper deck together while jamming to some deep-brain-stimulating music. We also hope our car will spark thought and conversation about our nation's complicated relationship with the bison.
In the future, our goal is to become a stage for historians, environmentalists, conservationists, and other groups and organizations who are passionate about the bison and seek to spread knowledge and awareness.
And of course... we'll be organizing music-focused get-togethers so we can dance together and make new memories outside of Black Rock City.

The Kindred Spirit Team

The Kindred Spirit team is a diverse bunch from the East Coast, with a healthy blend of Burning Man veterans and virgins filling the ranks. We're a crew of builders, artists, programmers, DJ's, musicians, entrepreneurs, and dreamers. Several of our folks have been members of art car crews in the past and have well-rounded knowledge of what it takes to build a project of this scale.

We all bring different skills, passions, and areas of expertise to the table, and we're all committed to seeing Kindred Spirit shine...

Other Ways You Can Help

Kindred Spirit is our gift to the Burning Man community...

You can always help us by spreading the word about the car and sharing this campaign among your friends! For more information please check out our Facebook page, and follow us on Instagram!

Stay tuned for more updates from the Kindred Spirit crew as the Burn gets closer!

<3 THANK YOU AND SEE YOU IN THE DUST! <3



Fundraiser video credits:

Music:

Surrounded by Silence (Robert R. Hardy Remix) - Tioan
Proton Music

MOJP photo credit:

Damien Noble Andrews Photography

story:
Imagine going to a theatre where you are invited to be part of the play by dining on stage while you interact with the actors and immerse yourself in the scenography. This is what we want to achieve:  a culinary interactive play that envelops the diner to experience all senses through food installations and immersive interiors. Immersive dining. 

We want to introduce this concept to unique venues like museums and theatres so as to make them alive by presenting collection or movie inspired dinners. Imagine museum rooms with actors taking you back in time to savour the dishes of that period, inviting you to enter into another dimension, a gastronomic experience of past times.

By involving actors, performers and artists, and food stylists we are aiming to build long lasting relationships with professionals who are passionate about this venture and create new opportunities for them.  The incredible response following the advertising of a post to assist with our events , and the passion that gave away through the application really inspired us  to make this project real:  "...I then went onto your website to look at your past work and think its absolutely brilliant. I am in third year and have been having real trouble deciding what to do when I graduate, but looking at Barrel and Forks has made me so excited to see the possibility of combining two real passions of mine"

An enthusiastic group of professionals is the first thing we need to realise this project. We will need the skills, passion and engagement of each individual in the team to perform Barrel & Forks concept.

By backing our project through the purchase of tickets to our future pop up dinners, you will be actively supporting us through setting up a laboratory to create and build installations, artists and actors remuneration, venue hire, kitchen equipment, buying materials to create decorations and table setting and props. Depending on the value of your contribution, as a bonus you will be treated to private chef and cooking classes experiences in the comfort of your home.

We’ve already invested a lot of time and money into this project and we’re commited to making it a success. We are also confident that this project wil work in that we had a great response to these dinners  in other occasions.  We started off with the Unconventional Dinner in October 2015, a theatrical dinner that challenged social conventions through its actors, the way food was served,  and the set up of the room. 

Our latest project, the Gladiator's Dinner, was set in the beautiful crypt of St. Pancras Church, this being the first time a dinner was taking place in the Crypt.

Our future projects include a Star Wars themed Dinner... We need more funds to make more evenings like this possible! Please help us make our dream come true!

story:
Hello my name is Jamie Haug; I grew up all my life on the same block, in the same house, and in the same neighborhood with a passion for making movies. It was not until I adventured to Santa Fe New Mexico that I got a grasp of the film life and industry. I am creating this indiegogo to help raise money for my senior thesis film. I would like to show the board members of the school, peers and especially my family that I have benefited and earned my B.F.A. from Santa Fe University of Art and Design.

We are looking to raise $2500 for the whole production and post-production of the film titled “Lady Bug”.

The film is an experimental Neo-noir

Lady Bug is about a young man that believes he is ready to climb the criminal latter and be once like this father. However our “hero” is caught in his own trap in which he needs to figure out the true path that needs to be taken.

The money we raise as a whole production would go to equipment rentals such as a RED camera, tech trucks or a U-Haul and other essentials that can aid us in the film. In addition, location permits, transportation for the cast and crew,food for a four day shoot, festival fees and possibly swag; posters, t-shirts, buttons, ect.

I would like to prove to those who are working on this project that they have a strong willed individual that can lead them to success. Furthermore, I want to prove that I know what it takes to create a film from the first page of a script to reaching  the martini shot. I never get tired of grabbing a few buddies and my DSLR to go out and shoot a fun film, but I have come to that point in my film career that I need to show the world that I and many others have the skills needed to succeed in the field of film. Above all, I want to create a film that is professional and well-recognized around the world.

To conclude, this project at the end of the day will help me graduate, but that is not the point. It’s to show who is working on this project to help promote their skills to the world. I understand that this film won’t win us an Oscar, but more importantly it will help exhibit what each individual can do and what we can aspire to do.

Making a movie is not a one person job; it is a collaboration of many.


Lead role Marcus: Jerome Arrey

Leading role Rodney: Daniel Williamas

Director & Writer: Jamie Haug

Producer & Editor: Chris Hanna

Directors of Photography: Daniel Seymour & Nick Ortiz

story:
Description

Hello, I am Ana-Maria Răducan and I am in love with drawing and painting. I want to help you art up your house with paintings that you’ll love. I will give my very best for each painting that I’ll make, so that it will be right for you.

I know that it won’t be easy, but I am confident that I will make it! And having your support will make me stronger. And knowing that people have supported me with all their hearts will make me work on the paintings all the more.

I hope that all art lovers will take a look at this campaign, and even if you cannot support me financially, if you share or tell people about me, it means a lot to me!


About me

I am studying English and Japanese in Cluj Napoca, Transylvania.

This year, my Japanese teacher at the university has chosen me as an exchange student at Kobe University in Japan. I was told that I might not get funded for this scholarship and asked if I still wanted to try. Hoping for the best, I said that I want to go no matter what. In February, Kobe University e-mailed us saying that this program was not funded and that I won’t get a scholarship. I couldn’t believe my eyes. Only then have I realized that I might not be able to fully sustain myself at university there. But I didn’t want to give up.

Being in love with drawing and painting, I have decided to use this as a means of sustaining myself. When my fiancé told me about this website, I knew that this is the right place for me.


How will I paint and what?


Gallery

Below are some of my paintings and drawings (some are fan art) and they should help you make an impression of what I can paint, draw and the style I usually adopt.

I am always open to new ideas or styles!


Here is a link to more drawings and paintings made by me: DeviantArt Portofolio


Shipping and timeline

The digital paintings will be sent via email. You will be able to print them in any size you need.

The oil paintings will be detached from the frame and put in protective tubes. This is the safest way to make sure the painting is not damaged during shipment. I will also send you the frame in case you want to frame it yourself and detailed instructions on how to assemble the painting. You will have to work a little before you’ll be able to fully enjoy it to the fullest, but it’s definitely worth it and I assure you, you’ll be proud of yourself at the end. As an alternative, you could also go with it to a carpenter to help you out.

I will ship the drawings in the order you supported me. It seems only fair to my first contributors. Anyway, I will be in contact with each of you and I will send you, if possible, a tracking code to be able to follow your parcel.



Pricing and perks

I know art can be expensive and that you don’t always get what you want. With your help, I want to make sure that this is not the case. I want to give you affordable, original art which matches what you want!

Unfortunately, if you want to buy more than one painting, you will have to pay the shipping for each perk. If there is interest for a combined perk, please let me know and I will create a corresponding perk.


Share to win

Even if you may not be able to support me financially, you can still give me a hand by sharing this campaign and telling people about it.

If you don’t have an Indiegogo account, make one right now and then scroll back here. Done? Good, to your left you will see a share button. Use this link to invite your friends to support me.

Every week I will draw from the pool of sharing persons a lucky winner to get the triptych of 3 digital drawings, absolutely free of charge. But once a month, the person with most shares that month will get a free oil painting 40x60 cm (15x23 inch), shipping included.

So, what are you waiting for? Click that share button!


Final thanks

In addition to supporting me in this campaign, you will receive special prices for other commissions you might want to order from me after this campaign ends. Depending on where you are, we might also meet up and chat. I’d love it!

Last but not least, I would like to thank you all for reading this far, sharing and supporting me!
