protective tubes. This is the safest way to make sure the painting is not
 damaged during shipment. I will also send you the frame in case you 
want to frame it yourself and detailed instructions on how to assemble 
the painting. You will have to work a little before you’ll be able to 
fully enjoy it to the fullest, but it’s definitely worth it and I assure you, 
you’ll be proud of yourself at the end. As an alternative, you could 
also go with it to a carpenter to help you out.
I will ship the drawings in the order you supported me. It seems only fair to
my first contributors. Anyway, I will be in contact with each of you and I
will send you, if possible, a tracking code to be able to follow your parcel.


Pricing and perks
I know art can be expensive and that you don’t always get what you 
want. With your help, I want to make sure that this is not the case. I 
want to give you affordable, original art which matches what you want!
Unfortunately, if you want to buy more than one painting, you will have to pay the shipping for each perk. If there is interest for a combined perk, please let me know and I will create a corresponding perk.

Share to win
Even if you may not be able to support me financially, you can still give me a hand by sharing this campaign and telling people about it.
If you don’t have an Indiegogo account, make one right now and then scroll back here. Done? Good, to your left you will see a share button. Use this link to invite your friends to support me.
Every week I will draw from the pool of sharing persons a lucky winner to get the triptych of 3 digital drawings, absolutely free of charge. But once a month, the person with most shares that month will get a free oil painting 40x60 cm (15x23 inch), shipping included.
So, what are you waiting for? Click that share button!

Final thanks
In addition to supporting me in this campaign, you will receive special prices for other commissions you might want to order from me after this campaign ends. Depending on where you are, we might also meet up and chat. I’d love it!
Last but not least, I would like to thank you all for reading this far, sharing and supporting me!

story:
My story so far~


   I am a qualified Architectural and Decorative glass artist.  Since graduating in 2005 I have run my small business. Attending craft events and doing events such as country living show.   I love what I do and currently work with several different techniques to make one off pieces of glass art.

   I have recently moved to a larger studio space, which will allow me to expand and develop in new areas. Such as silk screen printing on glass and perhaps even another kiln to allow me to do more casting work.  making my own molds to cast glass into I would like to offer small group workshops. Working with them to make a small stained glass panels, during a weekend workshop  I will provide materials, tuition, lunch and refreshments.  

  However this will require some cash input in order for me to expand.  I will need to by safety equipment for pupils, extra sets of tools and soldering irons.  materials  and a light box. I currently have no heating, which I can handle and work through the cold.  But its west coast Scotland it is cold and wet.  I hope to put in some heating for my pupils but also to keep the studio damp free.
  A new medium size kiln and some modelling and mold making supplies.  Along with a small silk screen printing table, screens and possibly a UV exposure unit. 
Some fixtures and fittings to keep space safe and uncluttered.



How can you help?


Im hoping to raise £2000 to help me on my way.

£500 will be used for workshop tools and materials

£500 to set up silk creen printing 

£400 to help fit out studio with shelving and heating

£600 will go towards a new kiln and mould making equipment.  Along with any extra finance that I will create due to expanding in new avenues.


Community impact-

  Living in Argyll, Scotland we are surrounded by beauty.  I would love to help people within the community use that inspiration to make there own little piece of glass art.  
I have worked with children before to design a stained glass window for our local hospital, which I went on to make and install.  It was a wonderful project and enjoyed by all. And still a much admired piece of community art.


So why help?


   Sometimes everyone needs a little help along the way.   I have been working in glass for 10 years now and I love what I do.  My head is full of ideas and new things to try.  But with day to day business overheads I struggle to get to that next stage to progress the business and ideas. So I am asking for a little help along the way.  And in return think i will be giving something back to others.

Even if you cant help financially then maybe help spread my cause. And help get me and A Touch of Glass Studio out there!!

Thank you for reading x

story:
Hi my name is Looksorn and I am a BFA with a concentration in photography at George Mason University in Virginia.

To graduate, every art student at George Mason is required to create a concise body of new work that is shown in the senior exhibition. My work is a documentary photography project about the ice factory that my family runs in Thailand. The series is composed of photographic portraits of people, processes, and machinery that make up the ice making business. Special emphasis is given to the laborers in the factory, most of whom are new immigrants to Thailand from nearby Myanmar (formerly Burma). A selection of stories related to these workers will be included with their portraits.

The body of work will be 16 photographs of 11" x 14" silver gelatin prints and 6 photographs of 32" x 32" inkjet prints. The money that you may kindly contribute will be used for custom made shadow box frames and window mats. Any help will be much appreciated.

The exhibition will be held on May 6th from 6 - 9 PM at the George Mason Art and Visual Technology Building.






See my work in progress here

story:
AVENTURE VISUELLE ET LITTÉRAIRE SUR LA ROUTE MYTHIQUE.

Beaucoup plus qu'une simple expo
Beaucoup plus qu'un autre projet sur la Route 66


Chers supporteurs
Nous sommes heureux de vous présenter notre projet qui consiste à créer une exposition où images et textes seront omniprésents. Pour ce faire, nous avons besoin de vos contributions financières pour parcourir la Route 66 durant 21 jours ( du 6 au 26 septembre 2016) et couvrir tous les frais inhérents à une expo digne de ce nom. Sillonner la Route 66 nous permettra d'amasser le matériel visuel et littéraire nécessaire pour une  présentation dans une galerie de Montréal.

Les œuvres exclusives ainsi crées seront présentées en très grand format, permettant aux amateurs d'art, de routes et de liberté de s'imprégner d'un monde fascinant, révélé sous l'angle combiné de deux créateurs.

Ce projet est né de la nécessité de fusionner nos formes personnelles d'expression pour les propulser vers une dimension nouvelle où se côtoient images, récits et émotions.

Notre volonté la plus chère avec ce projet est de vous propulser dans cette inspirante épopée de sorte que vous la viviez, la ressentiez et que vous deveniez un témoin privilégié d'une Amérique en mutation.


Pourquoi la 66 comme source d'inspiration

La 66 est une route incroyablement riche de vécues et de vibrations. Elle passe par un développement magistral entre le début du siècle jusqu'après la guerre. Elle subit, dans l'indifférence générale, une dégradation progressive pendant cinquante ans, période durant laquelle elle perd peu à peu les traces de son vécu exceptionnel.  Mais voici que, grâce à la volonté  de ses adorateurs, elle revient peu à peu à la vie. Cette étape représente un tournant important de son histoire qui mérite d'être vue, transmis et ressenti. Par son biais, c'est la transformation d'une Amérique entière qui y est incarné. Par notre démarche artistique, nous devenons une sorte de courroie de transmission de cet réalité unique dans le temps et l'espace.

En axant notre projet sur le sujet de la Route 66, nous participons à notre manière à la garder vivante.



Le Projet 66 est:

  • une démarche artistique globale (De l'idée au produit final).
  • Une volonté d'exprimer une réalité unique.
  • Un partage de l'histoire, d'un vécu.
  • Un témoignage d'un moment fixé dans le temps et l'espace.

Ce que ce projet n'est pas:

  • Ce n'est pas un guide de voyage.
  • Ce n'est pas une vacance ou un voyage d'agrément.
  • Ce n'est pas un documentaire.


Qui sommes-nous!

Marc et Caroline sont des artistes qui partagent la passion de la photo et de l'écriture ainsi que l'amour de la route.


Caroline: Riche de son expérience comme auteure et éditrice de guide de voyage Ulysse et de divers articles traitant de certains pays d'Afrique qu'elle a parcouru, Caroline a su développer son style d'écriture sous forme de journal où s'entremêle informations, description narrative et introspection. Par ses mots elle nous fait vivre le monde comme si nous y étions.


Marc: Suite à un retour à la photographie en 2014 et fort de ses 20 années d'expériences de technicien en audio et vidéo dont les huit dernières années dans un environnement muséal, Marc possède tous les outils pour élaborer et proposer une exposition contemporaine.  Depuis son retour, il ne cesse de développer son propre style loin des courants populaires.


Participez à l'aventure Ce dont nous avons besoin
 
Cette campagne nous permettra d'amasser les fonds afin de :

  • Parcourir la route historique de 4000 km, de Chicago à Los Angeles, pour amasser du matériel artistique.
  • Monter une exposition dans une galerie de Montréal.

Ce que vous obtenez:

  • Vous deviendrez, en notre compagnie, un témoin privilégié des efforts d'une communautés à préserver leur précieux héritage.
  • Vous aurez la chance de vivre l'ensemble de l'aventure par le biais d'un blogue. 
  • Vous aurez accès à la galerie virtuelle.
  • Vous aurez la satisfaction de participer à la réalisation d'une œuvre exclusive.
  • Vous serez les témoins, d'un processus de création.
  • Vous serez tenus au courant en continu des développements du projets.
  • Vous recevrez une Invitation VIP au vernissage de l'exposition.

Pour plus de détails sur les avantages, consultez la liste des contributions dans la colonne de droite.



Détails sur le budget
Pour parvenir à notre objectif,nous avons besoins de 12 000$ qui serviront aux coûts de déplacement et à la post production des photos et de l'exposition.

Budget (en dollars canadien)
 
Phase 1: Sur la Route  (pour deux personnes)

Déplacement Montréal Chicago : $300
Location de voiture (assurance et kilométrage) : $3500
Essence : $500
Repas : $1800
Hébergement : $1800
Frais connexes (ex: parcs et musées) : $500
Avion pour deux - retour Montréal : $600
Sous-total : ($9000)

Phase 2: Exposition

Frais galerie : $1000
Frais Impression de photos et encadrement: $2000
Sous-Total: $3000

Grand total: $12000


Par l'entremise de vos contributions et de votre participation à notre campagne, vous devenez un membre à la fois du projet et de notre équipe. Nous sommes impatients de vous amener avec nous dans cet extraordinaire périple. Un grand merci d'avance pour votre contribution.

Aidez-nous à répandre la bonne nouvelle!

Que vous pouviez ou non contribuer financièrement, nous vous serions très reconnaissant si vous pouviez partager notre projet sur vos réseaux sociaux tels que Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Google+, vos blogues ou tout autre endroit que vous jugerez pertinent.

Un très grand Merci

story:
Short Summary

 

Hi, I'm Tania and I am on a mission to help the underprivileged women of Delhi by providing them with a sustainable and respectful income through my Clay Studio. I also want to reduce the use of fresh flowers which when disposed improperly can bleed fertilisers and waste into the land and create havoc with the groundwater. The clay flowers Tania Clay Studio makes are photo-real, customised, exquisite and forever! We invite you to be part of our journey.

The women in the studio were working as daily labourers and maids in Delhi and are from troubled backgrounds. But now they are proud staff in the studio. They have worked hard to learn the art of making beautiful, customised clay pieces. Each piece they create adds a special touch to the clients magic moments and helps them provide for their families. We welcome you to view them through the video and personally if ever you are in Delhi.

 

Some Product Examples

 

  • The image shows the flower pots we have made. Each flower pot is a gift as part of a wedding.

  • An example of a wreath used for a wedding decoration.

  • Some marigolds for the festive season. Looks as real as it can be.. and no waste!

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

The Studio has made a good start and I am proud of what we have achieved in the last 7 years. But we are barely scratching the surface. There is a lot more to do and we need funds for this. Funds from this campaign will be used for PR & Marketing and to provide gainful employment for more underprivileged women.

  • We need $2500 per month to run a sustained SEO, Advertising and PR campaign to be able to advertise at the various trade fairs, magazines, events and retail outlets. Cost for 6 months is $15,000 which is the minimum time required for the campaign to show results.
  • We would like to get each of our present employees certified by Deco Clay Japan. It will cost us $500 per person to get them certified. We need $7500 to complete this.
  • Finally we need to increase the number of orders to be able to employ more women. We are looking to invest the remaining $13,500 to employ at least 10 more women to take the total staff to 25 women by end of this year.

 

Since this money will be going towards the expansion of the studio, I will be running a flexible campaign and whatever money I am able to raise will go towards uplifting more women and generating a positive buzz about the studio, its women, our mission and our beautiful products.

We are excited to offer you great perks which will go towards these goals. Take a look at the amazing perks we are offering and grab them as stocks last.

 

The Impact

 

There are real world impacts of this campaign. Some of the main ones are:

  • We are an all women studio working towards empowering other women in Delhi, India.
  • Every woman we hire is from the slums of Delhi and working in difficult conditions as daily labourers or maids in the extreme weather. Their lives are immeasurably improved by your contributions which will allow us to train them and hire more of them.
  • Your contributions will allow us to get more orders, hire more women. These women in turn are able to work in safe, secure and comfortable conditions earning a reasonable wage which allows them to educate their children and live with their heads held high.
  • Tania Clay Studio has more than 90,000 likes and followers on Facebook. This is a real business with loyal, engaged customers. Your contribution will help us to do more for them and you.
  • We work with NGOs like Protsahan in Delhi to ensure we create the maximum impact when we hire new staff.
  • We would like to get the word out to reduce the use of fresh flowers. Waste from the improper disposal of fresh flowers is an issue worldwide and causes damage to the groundwater as chemicals and fertilisers leech into the water.

 

We welcome visits to our studio and are happy to link you with our staff to let you get a firsthand feel of the impact of your contribution.

 

Risks & Challenges

 

There are always risks in every campaign. But as you are funding a business that has been running for 7 years already, they are relatively low in this case. Some of them would be:

  • Regulation changes which make it difficult to import Japanese clay into India. This could be mitigated by shipping them through our Singapore offices.
  • We partner with rural artisans in Indian villages for our boxes and packaging. These might be stretched as we expand. We will have to diversify our sources of these materials.
  • Prices are rising and the Indian economy is witnessing a slowdown. Hence we are looking at such campaigns to expand globally and diversify our client base.
  • Tania Clay Studio has always had a controlled, yet strong growth. However, we need to market aggressively in the future without which we see our growth plateauing. Thus the need for funds so we can grow and create a larger impact in the world.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We would love to see you get your own perk, but if you can't contribute, then we understand and hope that you would help to:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Any exposure would help.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign on your social media pages and feeds and help us achieve our goals.

There are always risks in every campaign. But as you are funding a business that has been running for 7 years already, they are relatively low in this case. Some of them would be:

Regulation changes which make it difficult to import Japanese clay into India. This could be mitigated by shipping them through our Singapore offices.
We partner with rural artisans in Indian villages for our boxes and packaging. These might be stretched as we expand. We will have to diversify our sources of these materials.
Prices are rising and the Indian economy is witnessing a slowdown. Hence we are looking at such campaigns to expand globally and diversify our client base.
Tania Clay Studio has always had a controlled, yet strong growth. However, we need to market aggressively in the future without which we see our growth plateauing. Thus the need for funds so we can grow and create a larger impact in the world.


 
Other Ways You Can Help
We would love to see you get your own perk, but if you can't contribute, then we understand and hope that you would help to:

Please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Any exposure would help.
Please use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign on your social media pages and feeds and help us achieve our goals.

story:
Nota - Español

Por razones de eficiencia, solo  puedo publicar el contenido de esta campaña en un idioma. Así que te recomiendo usar la herramienta de traducción de google chrome para ver la campaña en español.

Note - Français

Pour des raison d'efficacité, je ne peux que publier le contenu de cette champagne dans une langue. Donc, je te recommande de te servir de l’outil de traduction de google chrome pour voir la campagne en français.

 

Short Summary

Thanks for taking a look at this crowdfunding campaign! I am Daniel Amaya a circus & tech artist originally from Bogotá, Colombia. 

I am willing to become a professional circus artist and take my skills to the next level. That is why I am joining the Centre Régional des Arts du Cirque Piste d’Azur, a circus school in the south of France, at the end of September 2019. 

The hardest part is done! After an intense three days audition, I have got selected out of among one hundred participants together with 6 other skillful acrobats, aerialists and jugglers to receive a 2 years training in ‘Circus and Movement artist’ degree. 

I did my bet. I risked everything to be where I am right now. I quit the comfort of a predictable future, I quit my social status, I quitted the safe zone and I quit the expectations of others over myself. Everything to follow this dream. Now I am asking you to join this bet and help me to reach the next goal. I am asking for donations to help cover the basic expenses for starting this trip. It is the visa and tuition fees and the transport expenses.

I would be super thankful if you help me to make this dream possible! Any money you donate will contribute directly to my development as a circus professional, and enable me to give more back to the circus community in Latin America, Europe and all around the world!

 

My story

There are some things in life that we don’t choose, but rather discover. That was my case with circus. Since always, I felt a genuine love for mathematics, which brought me to study Mechatronics Engineering at the National University of Colombia, a place where everything is possible as it is a crossroad for  scientists, artists, athletes, politicians, activists and even tourists. During my studies, I early discovered circus thanks to a group of young people that I used to see juggling and jumping around every single day, through my classroom window. It took me some time the let my curiosity lead me and go. ‘Could you teach my how to juggle?’ I asked them one day. That was the moment I truly discovered a passion.

In the back, the Science & Tech building where I used to take classes. In the front, me training with friends and failing a trick!

2013. Bogotá, Colombia.

Fast enough I became part of the unpredictable and fervent phenomenon of latin american street circus! In less than three years my circus hunger took me to visit half of Colombia and other four countries in South America! Of course... during the university’s vacations. For several years, I kept on studying engineering alongside circus on a separate empirical path until I found out that I could join them to create mind blowing universes and go where no one had gone before! At the end jugglers are "practical mathematicians" and that is exactly what I am looking for when I juggle: using the balls as brushes to paint every sort of ephemeral shapes in the air.

La Réalité Paramétrique was my first circus & tech performance. Here, I played with several algorithms I wrote to interact either with me or with the juggling props using a kinect sensor. 
2017. Toulouse, France.
 

In 2018, I had the opportunity to join the HIVE, a six month residency program in the south of France getting together 20 young creatives from all around the world in order to offer the set of conditions to let their imagination come true through a tangible project. I co-created the project Wearkit: interactive costumes for performing arts.

Take a look to this reportage that France 3 did about us (in french) at the very beginning of the residency: youtube.com/watch?v=vBHVTjL8ANs

This was a very challenging experience that questioned me in every sense, since the very professional layer until the most personal fibers. During the time our residency lasted, we had the opportunity to collaborate with other artists to create two interactive performances while trying to take a glimpse at the future of performing arts. It was like swimming into the darkness. We didn’t know where we were going, but I was really enjoying this new creation way. I was feeling glad of living this new version of myself that was not looking for the good answers but rather for the good questions. Nowadays, I think it was a really growing experience for my artistic being.

You can take a look to our creations during the residency here:
CTRL: vimeo.com/282113627
Intome: vimeo.com/267872243

This was the inflexion point. During the development of Wearkit, I have understood what I really wanted to work for: looking for the encounter of the three key points of my life: my body, math, and technology all around the circus language. 

I was only missing one thing: reaching the high level set of skills to clearly settle my departure point as a professional circus artist. So, I decided to join a circus school where I could receive training and get the set of tools to start my professional creation path. That is why you are reading this right now!
 

Eureka, my newest performance. This was the act I performed during the school auditions. Photo by: Polaco Zabala.

2019. Chía, Colombia

About the school

At the core of the Côte d’Azur region, the Centre Régional des Arts du Cirque PACA - Piste d’azur stands as high level contemporary circus preparatory and professional school. It is a member of the European Federation of Professional Circus Schools (FEDEC). It is also part of the ProCirK network together with the circus schools Arc en Cirque, in Chambéry, and Balthazar, in Montpellier; schools which issues a Level III “Circus and Movement Artist” qualification registered with the French National Register of Professional Certifications.

It is the place where I will try many ideas, and fail, and try again, and fail again, and eventually find something amazing, and then I will research again, and find something even more impressive and at some point I will find something really mind blowing, and beautiful, and clever and poetic at the same time and then I will say ‘Yeah!’.

The audition was a super intense experience! I was the very first one arriving to the school that day as I passed the night in my tent on the beach under a huge shiny full moon, which was a beautiful moment, until the seagulls woke me up at 5 am. We performed a super intense physical test for the first filter and at the next day we were less than half of the initial group. Then we were tested in acrobatics, dance, theatre, music, creative writing and of course in our disciplines. That was how I got to met the school from inside: the atmosphere, the tent, the nature around it, the students, the teachers and my future partners! I loved the idea of becoming part of it. Even though I didn’t really love the idea of living in Cannes (I prefer cities like Marseille or Medellín). I actually feel that the school is one of those few things that make the city worth it to visit. It is one of those kind of things that you don't find anywhere else.

I am so excited and thankful of being chosen out together with Thaïs, Juan Pablo, Lucie, Angela, Grégoire and Marie-Ange with whom I will share this two years adventure! I am looking forward to start this new path with you guys!

You can find more information about Piste d’Azur in:
http://www.pistedazur.org/ 
http://www.fedec.eu/fr/members/117-piste-d-azur---centre-regional-des-arts-du-cirque
 

This is the school’s main training space. Take from pistedazur.org

La Roquette-sur-Siagne, France.

The Cost

I am asking for donations to help cover the basic expenses for starting this trip. It is the visa and tuition fees and the transport expenses.

As a colombian citizen I have to start a student visa demand process directly in Bogotá which implies several administrative expenses. As this procedure has to be done in Bogotá, I need also to cover my round trip France - Colombia. Finally I have to cover the tuition fees and a bunch of bureaucratic expenses (if you live in France you might know what I mean).

For the last year I have been working hard to get savings to cover a year full-time studying. I have been performing, giving workshops and doing other random jobs like translations, event logistics and even offering personalized math classes! However it is not enough. The french embassy estimates that living expenses (location, food, transportation, etc) for students over one year are not less than 7380 euros (615 euros per month). But this campaign is focus specifically on the departure expenses. 

That is why I am extremely grateful for any donation or support you can provide to this goal, and I accept all the responsibility that comes along with your generosity investing the resources collected in this campaign exclusively on my circus development.

 

Rewards

I have created a series of rewards that express pretty well who I am and what my artistic project is about. I hope they will mean something to you and you can keep a nice souvenir, from a piece of artwork to a set of juggling knowledge or even an immersive circus short film!

I do a small parenthesis about the poster ‘Mi circo, pixel por pixel’ because I think you will enjoy it more when you understand what is going on here and also because I think it is super cool! So, to built this poster, I wrote an algorithm that takes the average pixel of every single photo of myself juggling since 2012 until today. Then I took a photo of Eureka, the act I performed during the school audition and I replace my costume by all the pixels that resulted from the previous algorithm. No Photoshop, only code lines! You see that little yellow spot? that was a juggling training day at the beach. Or you see the green one? It was a performance in a park of Bogotá.

In other words, this is my entire circus life resumed in one single image! Literally.

Mi circo, pixel por pixel. By Daniel Amaya.

Giving back

Some of you might know about my engagement with circus as a tool for social change. A major axis of my artistic project is to keep on sharing my knowledge and spreading opportunities for others to be able to dedicate their lives to the arts. 

I truly believe in the power of circus to change lives, and that is why I have worked hard together with the circus community since the very beginning. I started with the creation of festivals and meeting places in popular neighborhoods of Bogotá and Chía. Then I volunteered in many pedagogical processes using circus as the main tool in Dominican Republic, Haiti, Ecuador, Brazil and several isolated regions of Colombia from Tumaco until La Guajira. And most recently I volunteered at circus festivals and conventions like the French Juggling Convention and the European Juggling Convention. 

I have always thought that this is a path that we build all together.

The very first juggling workshop I offered to kids of my hometown. This was the departure of a series of events and workshops during several years in Chía and Bogotá.

2013. Chía, Colombia.

The most recent pedagogical experience I had, was a one week intense workshop in Tumaco, Colombia. After 6 years of traveling while performing or teaching circus techniques, I felt I had seen almost everything. Nothing so far from the true. Working together with the Centro Afro to bring some circus to this guys was one of the most charging experiences I have ever had. Thank you guys.

Intense Circus Workshop at the Centro Afro.

2019. Tumaco, Colombia.

 

How to help

Besides donating to this campaign here on Indiegogo, you can also make a real difference by sharing this page. Tell your friends, Email it to your colleagues, post it on Facebook, Tweet it, etc. Anything you can do to get the word out will help me, as will any words of encouragement and good luck. I really appreciate it!

I greatly appreciate you taking the time to read this and watch the video. Please get in touch if you have any questions or just want to say hello, I would love to hear from you!

story:
Introduction

My name is Courtney Ehn. My performing name is Rainbow Flyte. I am the sole proprietor of Rainbow Flyte Aerial Arts. I am an aerial silks performer and aerial arts instructor. I’m hired to attend and perform at festivals, weddings, reunions, park parties, company picnics, social events, birthday parties, anywhere entertainment is needed. As an insured instructor, I teach people everywhere I go when my tripod rig and silks are set up. I also have aerial students who come to my home for their one on one private lessons. I’ve been doing aerial silks since 2013 as a student myself, then in 2016 decided to go to circus school, the New England Center for Circus Arts in Vermont to receive my aerial teacher training certifications in aerial silks, hammock, lyra/aerial hoop and trapeze. My absolute passion in life is to teach people magic they never thought they could experience. Circus was a huge part of american history, as time moves forward we have moved away from that imagination play. I think it is important for children and adults to still have an interactive imagination through circus arts. To expand their minds and experience it rather than just observe the superhuman, amazing hand eye coordination of circus performers.  

Where you come in...

I would like to expand Rainbow Flyte Aerial Arts into not just performance and instruction, but to inspire movement, exercise and fun through object manipulation dance. I want people to get excited about moving their bodies. I believe it is important for everyone old and young to connect with their inner child and most healthy, happy selves. I want to be the person to show them how fun it is to learn new things especially between the brain and body. Though I need to increase my material list and have a larger option of activity for these workshops. Hence why I am here.

I’m asking the Indiegogo community to help Rainbow Flyte Aerial Arts share this experience. I wish to create a larger selection of objects to manipulate, dance toys and aerial equipment to encourage everyone to expand their idea of movement and dance. 

Your donations will help me get all materials necessary to continue my dream inspiring and encouraging people to follow their dreams, learn about the history and future of circus arts, pay my  Rainbow Flyte Attendants (second hand and booth operator) and help with future travel expenses so I can spread the word and share dance play with people around the country. Like the creation of circus itself, I live to spark imagination in the minds of all who wonder how I make a living being myself, sharing my creativity, dreams and motivation with everyone anywhere I go.

Costs of Materials:

Custom Rainbow Silk: $300

Custom tie dye aerial hammock: $175

Custom children’s aerial hoop: $150

Aerial Rope: $200

Aerial Ladder: $100

Contact Staffs: $35 x 3= 105

Veil Fans: $10 each x 20 = 200

Poi balls: $2ea x 10 = 20

Veil poi: $10ea x 10= 100

Endo Board: $275

Weighted flags: $118/set

Dance wings: $10 x 10= 100

Travel Trailer for all equipment: $1000-2000

I will also purchase extra rigging materials, thicker protective mats for the ground, gymnastics rosin, Rainbow Flyte motivational t shirts and any other accessories I may need along with shipping all these awesome gifts out.

One day I  would like to open my own center for circus arts but for now I enjoy traveling and meeting  all the people from all areas of the united states.

 

Expanding Minds...

I descend to invite those willing, to step up and learn firsthand what aerial silks is all about on the silks, a hammock or the lyra. Since aerial yoga is more common these days, I include instruction on how to use an aerial hammock for those who have or wish to have one at home. I enjoy sharing my talents with those brave enough to test their strengths or who just want to try new ways of exercise, dance or just to have a laugh.

But what about those people who don’t believe in themselves? The grounded ones. I meet so many people who shy away from attempting aerial arts because they don’t trust themselves. I want to cater to them as well. Strength and courage come in different varieties. I wish to be their encouragement for new experiences even if it isn’t off the ground. I want to open their minds to new things. So, I introduce my “circus toys” and teach those around me how to find their groove with whatever object in my toy box catches their eye. The goal is to expand, improve and experience their eye hand coordination, mind body connection, PATIENCE and artistic abilities, while controlling that object in order to create their own form of art.

Object manipulation is a form of mastery play or skilled performance in which a person or people physically interact with one or more objects. These skills are commonly recognized by CIRCUS, sports, magic and other everyday practices. Finding connections in one’s self builds confidence.

My small collection of objects I currently share with others are aerial silks, aerial hammock, aerial hoop, poi balls (LED color), contact staff, weighted flags, endo board, juggling balls, dance ribbon, veil poi, dance wings, veil fans, finger poi. I simply play and dance with these things so I can inspire others to try. AND THEY DO!  I love to teach, inspire and dance with men, women and children of all ages as a beginning to their own journey of obman dancercising (object manipulation dance exercising.)

 

Risks & Challenges

Risks and Challenges of my project are not meeting my goal by the time my campaign ends. This project is something I will never give up on so as long as I believe in myself and my dreams, I will overcome any obstacles. Circus is expensive so if my campaign doesn't work out, I will continue doing as I have done the last two years. Working to save and buy materials needed little by little. 

As my touring season comes to an end, I will have four months of winter to raise money and grow my interactive circus before travels begin again in March. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can find and share Rainbow Flyte on Facebook, Instagram, youtube and Rainbow's website at www.RainbowFlyteAerialArts.com. 

I appreciate all donations and shares. Sending love to all!!!

Though I need to increase my material list and have a larger option of activity for these workshops. Hence why I am here.
I’m asking the Indiegogo community to help Rainbow Flyte Aerial Arts share this experience. I wish to create a larger selection of objects to manipulate, dance toys and aerial equipment to encourage everyone to expand their idea of movement and dance. 
Your donations will help me get all materials necessary to continue my dream inspiring and encouraging people to follow their dreams, learn about the history and future of circus arts, pay my  Rainbow Flyte Attendants (second hand and booth operator) and help with future travel expenses so I can spread the word and share dance play with people around the country. Like the creation of circus itself, I live to spark imagination in the minds of all who wonder how I make a living being myself, sharing my creativity, dreams and motivation with everyone anywhere I go.
Costs of Materials:
Custom Rainbow Silk: $300
Custom tie dye aerial hammock: $175
Custom children’s aerial hoop: $150
Aerial Rope: $200
Aerial Ladder: $100
Contact Staffs: $35 x 3= 105
Veil Fans: $10 each x 20 = 200
Poi balls: $2ea x 10 = 20
Veil poi: $10ea x 10= 100
Endo Board: $275
Weighted flags: $118/set
Dance wings: $10 x 10= 100
Travel Trailer for all equipment: $1000-2000
I will also purchase extra rigging materials, thicker protective mats for the ground, gymnastics rosin, Rainbow Flyte motivational t shirts and any other accessories I may need along with shipping all these awesome gifts out.
One day I  would like to open my own center for circus arts but for now I enjoy traveling and meeting  all the people from all areas of the united states.
 

Expanding Minds...
I descend to invite those willing, to step up and learn firsthand what aerial silks is all about on the silks, a hammock or the lyra. Since aerial yoga is more common these days, I include instruction on how to use an aerial hammock for those who have or wish to have one at home. I enjoy sharing my talents with those brave enough to test their strengths or who just want to try new ways of exercise, dance or just to have a laugh.
But what about those people who don’t believe in themselves? The grounded ones. I meet so many people who shy away from attempting aerial arts because they don’t trust themselves. I want to cater to them as well. Strength and courage come in different varieties. I wish to be their encouragement for new experiences even if it isn’t off the ground. I want to open their minds to new things. So, I introduce my “circus toys” and teach those around me how to find their groove with whatever object in my toy box catches their eye. The goal is to expand, improve and experience their eye hand coordination, mind body connection, PATIENCE and artistic abilities, while controlling that object in order to create their own form of art.
Object manipulation is a form of mastery play or skilled performance in which a person or people physically interact with one or more objects. These skills are commonly recognized by CIRCUS, sports, magic and other everyday practices. Finding connections in one’s self builds confidence.
My small collection of objects I currently share with others are aerial silks, aerial hammock, aerial hoop, poi balls (LED color), contact staff, weighted flags, endo board, juggling balls, dance ribbon, veil poi, dance wings, veil fans, finger poi. I simply play and dance with these things so I can inspire others to try. AND THEY DO!  I love to teach, inspire and dance with men, women and children of all ages as a beginning to their own journey of obman dancercising (object manipulation dance exercising.)
 

Risks & Challenges
Risks and Challenges of my project are not meeting my goal by the time my campaign ends. This project is something I will never give up on so as long as I believe in myself and my dreams, I will overcome any obstacles. Circus is expensive so if my campaign doesn't work out, I will continue doing as I have done the last two years. Working to save and buy materials needed little by little. 
As my touring season comes to an end, I will have four months of winter to raise money and grow my interactive circus before travels begin again in March. 
 

Other Ways You Can Help
You can find and share Rainbow Flyte on Facebook, Instagram, youtube and Rainbow's website at www.RainbowFlyteAerialArts.com. 
I appreciate all donations and shares. Sending love to all!!!

story:
All The World’s A Stage

Willie & Esther is a comedic and heartfelt story of a couple fighting to survive life in LA. While pushing to get to the next level they end up pushing the boundaries of their relationship hoping to eventually escaping their stark reality. Willie & Esther are portrayed by Danny De Lloyd and Malika Blessing. Danny and Malika have been working hard to get to this day.  

This duo has enjoyed such accolades as actors:

Danny De Lloyd 

NAACP Theater award winner, Best Male Actor in a Series, Best Dramatic Actor of the Year.

Malika Blessing

LAWebfest award for Best Dramatic and Comedy Actor and NAACP Theater nominated actress

Willie & Esther is a compelling production produced by Pamela Goodlow-Green with NAACP Theater Award winner Tiffany Rebecca Royale as the director.  This amazing Samuel French published play was written by James Graham Bronson and includes a special guest appearance by Jimmy Walker, Jr.

Theater is an important aspect of the performing arts world. So many that we see on TV and at the movies started on stage. It is where raw talent is displayed and where there are no retakes.  Our goal is to bring the audience the best production we can and to do this we need your help, .

What We Need & What You Get

To create the best possible production, we need to raise $10,000. The funds will be used to pay for our location, crew, set materials, and marketing. There are many moving parts to creating a quality show.

The Impact

Deeply rooted in the theater world, the cast and crew understand the importance of producing a high quality show. We also know the importance of giving back to the community. As a result, a portion of the proceeds will be donated to a youth arts program. 

Risks & Challenges

  • Our perks are obtainable. The risk in this campaign is minimal. Our team will work hard to ensure all perks are delivered as promised.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that sometimes our supporters cannot donate, we ask that you share our campaign on all your social media and email. Every little bit helps.

story:
The Ei-Robot helps you make your own Burning Man Art! 

Once the Ei-Robot is built it will help people build 4-foot diameter illuminated steel sculptures in real time at the Burning Man event. Artists, maybe even you or someone you know, will be able to make a design at home and submit it to us. If it is selected, it will created during our live performance at the Burning Man event, and the steel sculpture will be a big permanent art object long after. The light effect alone from the showers of sparks mid-air will be wondrous to behold. Even more powerful will be magical memories of the lucky few who get to watch their digital designs manifested before their very eyes on playa. Your support helps us help others have the ultimate Burning Man experience. How cool is that? 

Our lead artist is known locally, at Black Rock and Tucson, for his Chiminea Planetaria, a set of six hand-carved spheres that are internally illuminated. The 4-foot spheres create light and shadow art that are a wonder to behold. His new creation, the Ei-Robot, takes his legacy a step further by building a machine to carve YOUR designs LIVE on playa. 

How it works!

The Ei-Robot lifts the spheres into the air, where a CNC plasma cutter makes the magic happen. Here's our CAD-model in action! 

 

In addition to donating to our campaign, participants can submit a design for an art sphere! Please submit your idea in the form of a black and white drawing 1800 pixels high by 4800 pixels wide. Anything black will be removed (cut away) from a sphere by Ei-Robot, so avoid any floating "islands" of white in your design, such as the center of a letter ”O”. We encourage you to dream big and be creative any way you like. If you're interested, let us know and we can help.  Please submit your design by August 18th, 2018 through email to ArkaneArts@gmail.com

 

Two of the Chiminea Planetaria. The Ei-Robot spheres will be similarly proportioned, but designed by YOU! Make it happen with a donation. Please donate today!

 

The Inspiration

The image below is from our 2016 Burning Man piece, Chiminea Planeteria. The Ei-Robot finished products will be similar in size, only designed by participants. 

The inspiration for this project came from the mighty Egg-Bot. A miniature machine that draws designs on eggs. The Ei-Robot will be enlarged 100-fold, and outfitted with a plasma cutter to carve into steel spheres on scene.  

Meet the Ei-Robot Crew! 

Spencer "Quicksilver" Edgerton, the lead visionary will be celebrating his 10th burn with the Ei-Robot crew this year.  This talented individual has experience with metal-working at all scales, from jewelry-making, bronze casting, blacksmithing, public art, fine art and more. 

Amanda "Golden" Smith, wearer of many hats. Water policy scientist by day, art supporter by night. She is the treasurer and moral supporter of this project.

Liz "Scout" Cameron, a spunky metal theorist, patient teacher and the one who's always ready with that thing-you-didn't-know-you-needed. 

The rest of the support team!

story:
The Robert Henri Roadtrip and Residency

When I came across signs for the Robert Henri Museum driving with my wife on Highway 80 from Julesburg to Lincoln, I said "We have to stop!". When I learned they have a residency program I said "I gotta apply!". When I got word that I was selected for 2018 I immediately thought "Lets make a documentary of this!"

It's going to be a whirlwind roadtrip painting the way from LA to Cozad in the first place. Then the residency itself: 21 days of all painting all teaching and getting people excited for paint, life, art and spreading the word about all things painting and plein air. We want to teach Nebraska to paint, and then teach the world. It will be the best Art School Painting Education they may ever get and dedicated in name and Spirit to it's native son Robert Henri.

And We Wanna Film It!

I want to be able to remember this and share it with more than just the people experienced on the journey, so I the need to fund another artist to join me, a filmmaker and documenter who I have worked with before, Luke Homay productions. The first roadtrip documentary we made years ago was amazing, and with all we've learned since then, this will be even better!  We are on a mission

What We Need & What You Get

I think this is going to be a film-worthy journey and I need a professional to make a quality video of this once in a lifetime experience. I hope to have a positive impact on the people I meet in Nebraska, and I want everyone who watches the documentary to feel some of that too!

That's where Luke Homay comes in, the ideal travel partner. First off he is an excellent artist with gear and expertise in all aspects of film making. Secondly we are friends and have collaborated before on similar projects so we get along great. Third he is as excited about the documentary as I am for the residency so we are both GEARED UP!

Reality sets in pretty quick and you realize time is money which explains this fundraiser. There are some things that are covered by the program when we get to Cozad, but there are always expenses all the time and part of your donation will go toward costs of the road and ensuring we don't have to worry about anything but the residency and the film. Luke would like to get a few pieces of needed gear for his setup as well, such as drone camera, good sound and a variety of camera rigs. I need lots of tubes of color and art supplies and we all know they aren't cheap.

When you contribute you get stuff in return. On the good times side of things, besides the happy feeling of helping us out, you are also allowing a great documentary of a unique experience get made which could tune a lot of people into painting and art not only here but around the world.  On the tangible side of things you will, of course receive a dvd copy of the documentary for your collection for all levels of donation. You could get postcard drawings sketched on the trip and mailed to you. Paintings! Original art by Alex Schaefer! Artist choice, your choice. Works from the trip! landscapes, cityscapes, portraits etc

story:
Our names are Selina and Justine Latour. We are twins originating from Ottawa, Ontario, now living in Montreal and Berlin respectively.  We’ve been accepted at the Buinho Creative Residency Program in Messejana, Portugal, for the months of January and February 2019! This two month period is something we’ve been greatly looking forward to, as it will enable us the time towards developing our collaborative art practice after spending the last 6 years apart.

As identical twin sisters, we have grown up learning and absorbing each other’s ways of thinking. After studying separately in different fields (Selina in Fine Arts and Justine in Fashion Design), our ideas have continued to reflect one another’s, but our individual practices have expanded into different forms. With this residency opportunity, we are now looking forward to discovering ways to combine our skills to create works that are doubly strong.

In the last year, we worked from afar to start up a textile collaboration. Through this work, we spoke to our experiences of twinhood - intuitively working together to form images about femininity, togetherness and intimacy. We began to make clothing that combined Selina’s illustrations and textile designs with Justine’s pattern drafting and sewing skills. We named our collaboration Burnt Design, and we organized a couple of pop up shops in Toronto to begin funding this residency.

We are excited about this opportunity at Buinho, not only to continue our work in textiles, but also to finally share the time and space together to nurture a collaborative multidisciplinary practice. The Buinho Creative Residency Program offers a Fab Lab facility, giving us access to innovative technologies (laser cutter, 3D printer, Arduino boards) that can help us to develop our mutual interests in creating installation and performance work.

Your help in funding this residency will help us to cover material costs in the projects we envision making, some basic living costs (food, lodging) as well as the travel costs to get us there. Any little bit helps - whether it’s a few dollars here or there to cover a grocery bill, pay for the bus from Lisbon to Messejana, or fund our analog photography expenses. Primarily, your financial support will allow us to achieve our creative projects!

We have a few perks to offer to express gratitude for your support: a small print (photo/watercolour or the like) for $15.00, a publication we intend to make from our photography in Messejana for $35.00, a Burnt hat design for $40.00, and/or a mystery piece for $55.00.

We are so excited to arrive in Messejana to begin expanding on this collaboration!  We look forward to making work and sharing it all with you!

Independent Websites:

http://www.jlatour.com/

http://selinalatour.wixsite.com/selinalatour

story:
The Project

How does someone become who they are (and who they think they are)?

My current project is a large-scale (7ft x 24ft), multi-layered tapestry piece that involves audio interviews as a "soundtrack" to the piece. The project seeks to question how growth occurs while a person is affected by environments, decisions, circumstances, and the intersection between self and others. Using ecological/botanical metaphor for human growth in a social environment, it will take the form of an embroidered/painted/collaged image of a forest to create an anthropomorphic character. Due to the variety of concepts that find their meeting point in the piece, I have been conducting different forms of research in artist residencies this year. I began with botanical/environmental research at Manassas National Battlefield Park, in addition to studying the primary source letters of Confederate soldiers written during the first battles of the Civil War. I then conducted personal one-on-one interviews during my residency at the Sheen Center For Thought & Culture in Manhattan. During these sessions, I sat down with the interviewees and asked questions pertaining to their personal experiences and self-identity while sketching their portrait. Audio segments from these interviews will be played from behind the tapestry during exhibitions and remain completely anonymous. Interview participants came from a NYC area open-call I created, as well as alumni from Rehabilitation Through The Arts, and Year Up New York (an organization that works to close the opportunity divide for young adults from underprivileged backgrounds). As a form of gratitude for participating, each interviewee received a portrait lithograph print created from the sketches made during their session. Prints from these editions are also available as a perk for contributions on Indiegogo.

At each venue that the piece is exhibited in, a recording booth will allow visitors (two at a time) to sit and ask one another one of the interview questions. The booth will be a simple wood structure fitted with an iPad that will use an app to randomly select one of the questions used in the interviews and then record the response. Their recorded responses will be incorporated into the tapestry's audio at the next exhibition venue. The show will be on view in the Sheen Center gallery (18 Bleecker st, New York, NY, 10012) from September 13-October 12th, with an opening reception on September 13th (6-8 pm).

 

Who am I?

I'm a NYC-based artist and educator originally hailing from Port Chester, NY. Through variety of texture and use of extensive layering, my work investigates the intersection between the specificity of our world—of a face—and the depth of the unknowable in reality. My pieces take form in tapestry, sculpture, painting, and installation—sometimes involving audio components. Isolation, aging, vulnerability, and the ways in which all of these factors affect our ability to know one another serve as just a few themes in my work. In an effort to understand what it means to honestly be "moved," many of my pieces address viewers individually, sometimes imposing themselves or calling to viewers in a way that physically establishes an almost private relationship between the piece and its visitor.

I received a Bachelor of Science in Visual Arts from SUNY Purchase School of Art + Design. I've exhibited in various New York venues and have been awarded Artist-in-Residence positions at the Sheen Center For Thought & Culture in Manhattan, NY and Manassas National Battlefield Park in Manassas, VA. My works can be found in the National Parks Foundation’s public collection and in private collections within the United States and Europe. I have most recently joined the governing body of Openings Artist Collective. I am currently an Art Educator with the New-York Historical Society, providing Art programs to students throughout NYC. I have previously taught Art in Brooklyn PreK-8 private schools, worked as a Teaching Artist for the NARS Foundation, and will be teaching High School art in the Fall. I have also assisted in art forensic and conservation projects for collections at the Hispanic Society of America Museum, PepsiCo Sculpture Garden, and TONDO Art Forensics Lab in Budapest, Hungary.

 

Funds Will Be Used For:

  • Equipment necessary for projecting the fragments of the interview audio. The individual voices will be on individual tracks in the audio file, and will be output to individual speakers placed in various locations in between the layers of the tapestry, creating another sense of depth in the piece. To achieve this, a laptop will need to feed the audio into two audio interface boxes that will control the output to each of the 15+ miniature speakers. This equipment constitutes the majority of the funding needs for this project. 
  • Materials for building the physical tapestry piece, including large-scale fabrics, thread stock, wood, epoxy, paints, hanging equipment, etc...
  • Materials for constructing the recording booth and purchasing iPad for booth.

In return, there are some cool perks, including private tours of the exhibition in NYC in September and wood lithography prints from those created during the "Who Are You?" interviews! Some of the prints can be found at the Saatchi Art Page.

 

The Impact

The project seeks to allow the voice of those traditionally excluded by the "jargon" of the Art world to narrate and inform my work directly. The oral history volunteered by participants in this project will be engaged with in communities outside their own as the piece travels to various exhibition locations. Those who have already served as interviewees have communicated their surprise and gratitude for the experience of discussing the specific questions asked about themselves and their experiences. I hope the tapestry piece and recording booth can encourage such conversations to happen within everyday relationships, and not only exist in social art projects. 
 

Challenges

It's a tight time frame that I have to finish the piece before its exhibition in September, but production is on schedule, and with your help I'll be able to spend less time finding thrifty "work-arounds" and will instead be able to purchase the right materials and devices to ensure the project can do what it is meant to do.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute to the fund, it's no problem! Share this campaign page and help spread the word (include the hashtag #whoareyouinterviews and tag my instagram page @jenncacciolastudio)!
Also, come to the show in September! You can stay updated by following me on Instagram @jenncacciolastudio or find updates and details in the "Current" section on my site http://www.jenncacciolastudio.com/

 

 

Many Thanks,

Jenn

Due to the variety of concepts that find their meeting point in the piece, I have been conducting different forms of research in artist residencies this year. I began with botanical/environmental research at Manassas National Battlefield Park, in addition to studying the primary source letters of Confederate soldiers written during the first battles of the Civil War. I then conducted personal one-on-one interviews during my residency at the Sheen Center For Thought & Culture in Manhattan. During these sessions, I sat down with the interviewees and asked questions pertaining to their personal experiences and self-identity while sketching their portrait. Audio segments from these interviews will be played from behind the tapestry during exhibitions and remain completely anonymous. Interview participants came from a NYC area open-call I created, as well as alumni from Rehabilitation Through The Arts, and Year Up New York (an organization that works to close the opportunity divide for young adults from underprivileged backgrounds). As a form of gratitude for participating, each interviewee received a portrait lithograph print created from the sketches made during their session. Prints from these editions are also available as a perk for contributions on Indiegogo.At each venue that the piece is exhibited in, a recording booth will allow visitors (two at a time) to sit and ask one another one of the interview questions. The booth will be a simple wood structure fitted with an iPad that will use an app to randomly select one of the questions used in the interviews and then record the response. Their recorded responses will be incorporated into the tapestry's audio at the next exhibition venue. The show will be on view in the Sheen Center gallery (18 Bleecker st, New York, NY, 10012) from September 13-October 12th, with an opening reception on September 13th (6-8 pm).
 
Who am I?I'm a NYC-based artist and educator originally hailing from Port Chester, NY. Through variety of texture and use of extensive layering, my work investigates the intersection between the specificity of our world—of a face—and the depth of the unknowable in reality. My pieces take form in tapestry, sculpture, painting, and installation—sometimes involving audio components. Isolation, aging, vulnerability, and the ways in which all of these factors affect our ability to know one another serve as just a few themes in my work. In an effort to understand what it means to honestly be "moved," many of my pieces address viewers individually, sometimes imposing themselves or calling to viewers in a way that physically establishes an almost private relationship between the piece and its visitor.I received a Bachelor of Science in Visual Arts from SUNY Purchase School of Art + Design. I've exhibited in various New York venues and have been awarded Artist-in-Residence positions at the Sheen Center For Thought & Culture in Manhattan, NY and Manassas National Battlefield Park in Manassas, VA. My works can be found in the National Parks Foundation’s public collection and in private collections within the United States and Europe. I have most recently joined the governing body of Openings Artist Collective. I am currently an Art Educator with the New-York Historical Society, providing Art programs to students throughout NYC. I have previously taught Art in Brooklyn PreK-8 private schools, worked as a Teaching Artist for the NARS Foundation, and will be teaching High School art in the Fall. I have also assisted in art forensic and conservation projects for collections at the Hispanic Society of America Museum, PepsiCo Sculpture Garden, and TONDO Art Forensics Lab in Budapest, Hungary.
 

Funds Will Be Used For:

Equipment necessary for projecting the fragments of the interview audio. The individual voices will be on individual tracks in the audio file, and will be output to individual speakers placed in various locations in between the layers of the tapestry, creating another sense of depth in the piece. To achieve this, a laptop will need to feed the audio into two audio interface boxes that will control the output to each of the 15+ miniature speakers. This equipment constitutes the majority of the funding needs for this project. 
Materials for building the physical tapestry piece, including large-scale fabrics, thread stock, wood, epoxy, paints, hanging equipment, etc...
Materials for constructing the recording booth and purchasing iPad for booth.

In return, there are some cool perks, including private tours of the exhibition in NYC in September and wood lithography prints from those created during the "Who Are You?" interviews! Some of the prints can be found at the Saatchi Art Page.

 

The Impact
The project seeks to allow the voice of those traditionally excluded by the "jargon" of the Art world to narrate and inform my work directly. The oral history volunteered by participants in this project will be engaged with in communities outside their own as the piece travels to various exhibition locations. Those who have already served as interviewees have communicated their surprise and gratitude for the experience of discussing the specific questions asked about themselves and their experiences. I hope the tapestry piece and recording booth can encourage such conversations to happen within everyday relationships, and not only exist in social art projects.  

Challenges
It's a tight time frame that I have to finish the piece before its exhibition in September, but production is on schedule, and with your help I'll be able to spend less time finding thrifty "work-arounds" and will instead be able to purchase the right materials and devices to ensure the project can do what it is meant to do.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you aren't able to contribute to the fund, it's no problem! Share this campaign page and help spread the word (include the hashtag #whoareyouinterviews and tag my instagram page @jenncacciolastudio)!Also, come to the show in September! You can stay updated by following me on Instagram @jenncacciolastudio or find updates and details in the "Current" section on my site http://www.jenncacciolastudio.com/
 
 
Many Thanks,
Jenn

story:
Sawubona! Thank you for clicking onto my crowdfunding campaign. My name is Luyanda Zindela. I'm a 24 year old fine artist, living and working in Durban, South Africa. I specialize in drawing, and the art I make mostly stems from my experiences and the people around me.

THAT ART FAIR, is an annual arts event that will take place on Cape Town, South Africa, from the 17th of February 2016 to the 6th of March 2016. This event, which takes place in Cape Town, one of the largest art markets on the African continent, is special in that one of its major aims is to provide a platform where young, unrepresented, emerging artists like myself can showcase our work in a professional environment and be seen by curators, collectors, galleries and new audiences. While THAT ART FAIR provides this amazing platform and opportunity to young artists like myself, all the costs that go into participating in an art fair like this one are to be covered by the artist.

Being selected to participate in THAT ART FAIR 2016, is a huge deal as it represents the first real chance I have as an artist to showcase my work, not just in an art fair, but an important art fair based in a key city. This is the first real chance for me to position myself as an artist within the local arts community.  


What Is Needed and what YOU get

With your help, I will be able to cover the costs needed to participate in THAT ART FAIR 2016. These costs include:

  • Transport to and from Cape Town, South Africa.
  • Accommodation in Cape Town for the duration of THAT ART FAIR 2016. 
  • The shipping of my artworks to Cape Town and back, if certain artworks aren't sold during the art fair.
  • Setting up a small exhibition stand (2m X 2m).
  • The printing of business cards, catalogs, and other professional material.
  • The making of project perks and rewards.
 Speaking of perks and rewards, a section of my exhibition stand will be dedicated naming and acknowledging all those who back this contribute to this campaign. Other cool rewards range from receiving a high resolution digital portrait of yourself drawn in my unique crosshatching style, sent to you via email, to being featured in one of my upcoming series of artworks! 

Risks & Challenges
  • The original portrait drawings will be relatively small (A5). High Res Images of the drawings can be printed to any size, however, arrangements can be made via email if you desire to have the original drawing.
  • The drawing of the portraits can be done fairly quickly, but drawing in my crosshatching style can be a bit more time consuming. 
  • Being featured in one of my new series of artworks will take time and a lot correspondence via email.

Although 2mX2m may seem like a small space for an exhibition stand, I am positive that with your help, that stand, however small, will be a striking one. Every contribution counts! from the financial to even the little bit of professional advice you may have, to help me make my spot in THAT ART FAIR 2016 the best it can be, to help me make a meaningful first impression on the South African art industry.
ASAMBE! Lets Get to the Cape!......   

Portraits (Sometimes I Choose to FOCUS on a certain Area)


Portraits 



Example of a friend in one of my Artworks
